item.title: Samara Fruit Tree Profile
item.description: Samara seeds are surrounded by a papery wing that, when the wind blows, carries the seeds farther away than most other fruit seeds.
item.content:encoded:
A samara is often found in large groups on a tree and not all samaras look alike. One familiar type of samara is the double-winged one found on maple trees (Acer spp.). Ash trees (Fraxinus spp.) produce a samara that features a single elongated wing. Elm trees (Ulmus spp.) produce samaras where the seed is located in the middle of a papery circle. These flowering plants all produce samara fruits after blooming.

Examples of other trees and shrubs that produce samaras:

  • Common hoptree (Ptelea trifoliata)
  • Flabellaria paniculata (a woody African vine)
  • Tree of heaven (Ailanthus altissima)
  • Tulip tree (Liriodendron tulipifera)
  • Also, one of the few legumes that produce a samara is the Tipu tree of South America.

Samara Fruit Tree Examples, Characteristics, and Care

One example of a tree that produces samara fruit is the Red Maple (Acer rubrum). It is a deciduous tree, native to Eastern North America from Quebec to Minnesota south to Florida and eastern Texas. In northern states, the Red Maple usually grows in wet bottomland, river flood plains, and wet woods. In the midwest, it tends to grow in drier, rocky upland areas. It is very cold hardy in USDA Zones 3 through 9. Spreading 30 to 50 feet wide, it grows 40 to 70 feet tall with a rounded to oval crown. Red maples grow faster than Norway or sugar maples, but slower than silver maples. All emerging new growth in the form of leaves, leafstalks, twigs, flowers, fruit, and fall foliage are red or tinged with red. Flowers are typically red, sometimes yellow, in large clusters, blooming from March to April. After the flowers, come the leaves. The leaves start dark green above and gray green below. They are 2 to 5 inches long with 3 or 5 primary triangular-shaped, toothed, pointed lobes. Samara fruit is also initially reddish producing a two-winged samara.

Winged Elm (Ulmus alata) is another deciduous tree that gives way to samaras. This elm is native to southern Virginia west to Kentucky, southern Indiana and Illinois, and central Missouri; south to central Oklahoma and southeastern Texas; and east to central Florida. It also grows in Maryland. When placed in an open area, branches arch upward to create a rounded crown. In a forested site, the tree grows taller and straighter. Naturally, Winged Elm can be seen growing freely in rock outcrops, dry wooded areas, and fields. Bark is red-brown to ash gray. Leaves have doubly toothed margins. In fall, they turn yellow and in late winter, small red flowers mature in clusters. The tree produces 1/4- to 1/2-inch flattened samara with hairy margins. Other common names for the Winged Elm are Cork Elm, Small Leaf Elm, Wahoo Winged Elm, and Witch Elm. Prune this tree regularly to prevent it from growing multiple trunks.

Common hoptree (Ptelea trifoliata) is native to Eastern and central United States, hardy in Zones 4 through 9. This native, deciduous tree is sometimes considered a shrub because it grows a modest 15 to 20 feet tall and wide. The hoptree is dense and rounded, making it an ideal specimen for a flowering hedge. Naturally, it grows in open woods, glades, ravines, thickets, and prairies. Leaves are shiny, dark green, each two to five inches long, turning greenish yellow in autumn. Fragrant, tiny clusters of tiny greenish white flowers bloom in late spring. These clusters of flowers produce clusters of seeds, each seed encased in a thin, winged one-inch samara. Seeds mature in late summer and last through most of winter. The common name of hoptree refers to the prior use of seeds as a substitute for hops. Other common names include wafer ash and stinking ash.

Light

Grow Red Maple and Winged Elm in full sun to part shade. Hoptrees can tolerate full sun but thrive in part shade to full shade.

Soil

While Red Maple will tolerate a wide range of soils, it prefers moist, slightly acidic soil that is well-draining. Winged Elm prefers moist to dry conditions in a variety of soil types that contain loam, clay, sand, or rock. Hoptree will also grow in dry to medium well-drained conditions.

Water

Plant Red Maples in a rain garden or another site where it is easy to maintain a medium to wet environment. Give Winged Elms and Hoptrees dry to medium moisture.

Are Samara Fruit Trees Toxic?

Be sure to research each tree, shrub, or plant for their toxicity. Red Maple is toxic to horses, but non-toxic to dogs and cats, according to the ASPCA. Wilted leaves are the most toxic part of the plant. Symptoms of poisoning include "destruction of red blood cells (anemia), weakness, dark urine, difficulty breathing, abortion, [and] death."

Tree of Heaven leaves are toxic to domestic animals, according to Purdue University, which also cautions that gardeners may experience rashes from the leaves and hay fever from the plant's pollen. However, the hoptree and tulip tree are largely known as non-toxic.

Harvesting Maple Seeds 

Maple seeds are more than a toy; they also have a pod with edible seeds inside. Remove the outer covering before eating the seeds from maple trees. When seeds are young and green in spring, they are known to be the most pleasant tasting. Sprinkle them into a salad or stir-fry or mix them into mashed potatoes. Since different varieties of maples produce samaras at different times of the year in certain areas, seeds might be available for harvest and consumption for an extended period. Store the seeds to continue eating them through summer, fall, and perhaps winter if you have enough to last a full year. Roast or boil them if mature seeds taste bitter.

Common Pests and Diseases

Aphids, borers, scale, and caterpillars are common pests to the Red Maple. Leafhoppers can cause the most substantial damage. Keep an eye out for verticillium wilt, canker, fungal leaf spot, and root rots. Branches are prone to breakage by wind and ice.

Borers, scale, and caterpillars may also attack the Winged Elm. Watch for beetles and leaf miners too. This tree is especially vulnerable to Dutch Elm Disease. Powdery mildew, phloem necrosis, cankers, and leaf spots can also cause issues on stressed trees.

item.title: The 7 Best Drill Presses of 2021
item.description: A good drill press is powerful, easy to control, and durable. We researched the features of the best models so you can pick the right ones for your projects.
item.content:encoded:
Drill presses are stationary tools–some stand on the floor while others sit on a workbench–with a sturdy and adjustable platform to hold the object being drilled, and an overhead chuck that holds the drill bit in place. Like a portable handheld drill, a drill press is a tool for making holes in wood or other hard materials, but drill presses go far beyond handheld drills in terms of power and precision.

A handheld drill is sufficient if you merely need to occasionally drill holes into wood for simple repairs or construction. But for drilling into very hard wood or metal, drilling through thick pieces of wood, producing large holes, drilling at an angle, or achieving the utmost in accuracy, a drill press is the tool of choice. We researched the top drill presses available today, and then whittled down the choices to those we feel are best in their categories.

Here are the best drill presses on the market.

It is all too easy to find the wrong drill press for your needs while shopping. Plenty of options promise the power you need for most construction projects but fail to deliver when needed. The WEN 12-Inch Variable Press, with a 12-inch swing and 3-1/8-inch stroke distance, is designed to skip the overselling and simply offers a powerful, straightforward drill press for your shop. With a maximum speed of 3,200 rpm and variable speed dial, the power and control this top choice press offers ​is clear.

The benefit of a variable speed dial is you can change the speed while maintaining the same power and torque you may need for denser materials. Using high-quality bearings and a rigid frame, the body of this drill press will resist heavy abuse while extending the life of the inner workings of the power tool. If you need a drill press you can count on to work time and time again, this option is hard to beat.

If you just want a drill press for precision work on small items such as jewelry, shells, wood trim, or model making, there’s no need for a large tool that will take up lots of space and provide more muscle than you need. Instead, consider the Eurotool DRL-300.00 Small Benchtop Drill Press.

With a platform measuring a mere 6.75 inches x 6.75 inches, and an overall size of 10 x 12 x 8 inches, the drill press easily fits into any workspace. But while it may be small, it’s not without power, although it’s certainly not designed for tackling the toughest drilling jobs.

The 110-volt motor achieves a top speed of 8,500 rpm, and there are three speed settings to choose from. The ¼-inch Jacobs chuck accepts bits up to 6.5 mm.

Not a true drill press, but rather, a workstation that allows you to use your Dremel rotary tool in a similar manner to a drill press, this workstation/drill press fits into the category of “small but mighty,” and is perfect for delicate tasks such as crafts, jewelry, or work on electronics. Your rotary tool fits into the workstation, allowing you to angle the tool at a variety of angles for your needs.

The workstation screws into a worktable for stability without taking up too much valuable space. Note, however, that it does not include the Dremel rotary tool; you'll need to purchase that separately if you don't already own one.

For the price, you actually get one of the most flexible drill presses available. The flex shaft attachment works with the drill to allow you to rotate the head for angled holes up to 90 degrees horizontal. A tool holder and router mount extend the capabilities of this press, enabling other work such as plunge routing and sanding/grinding to be done all in one workstation.

If you don’t mind giving up some performance and control out of a drill press, the WEN 4208 is a reasonably priced alternative that won’t break the bank. The press sacrifices the more flexible variable control dial for a five speed switch that extends all the way to 3,140 rpm. The 1/3-horsepower motor will get the job done on small to medium jobs and common construction materials, including very hard woods.

A cast iron base securely mounts to most worktables for a sturdy, stable hold. The included 6.5-inch x 6.5-inch beveling table is small but flexible, allowing you to tilt the drilling surface up to 45 degrees for angled drilling. This drill press has an 8-inch swing and a 2-inch stroke distance, meaning it's not designed to handle large, thick materials. The slots in the table are even large enough to accommodate mounting clamps and vises to secure the drilling surface to the table while tilting.

When it comes to drilling holes on the go, you probably think of handheld power drills. While these are the go-to choice for hobbyists and professionals alike, most power drills lack the precision some jobs require. When you need an additional guide, a lightweight option like the Ogrmar Drilling Collet Drill Press comes in handy. This ingenious device is far easier to transport than is an actual drill press.

Instead of forcing you to lug around a dedicated drill press, this tool allows you to secure your existing power drill into a tight, rotating clamp. This clamp holds the drill along the metal rail, giving you the finer degree of precision you need without the extra weight. The clamp rotates from 0 to 90 degrees, so you can even precision drill on vertical surfaces if you can place the press in the correct position.

A dedicated floor drill press offers the most in terms of professional capability and features. The Delta 18-900L is a top-of-the-line option that maximizes the power, control, and durability you can have out of a drill press. If you have a dedicated workshop or professional projects, this type of drill is an investment that will last you a long time.

Many professionals prefer floor drills since they don’t take up table space and, in fact, typically offer larger work surfaces underneath the drill. The 18-900L includes a 20 x 28 inch worktable that bevels up to 90 degrees left or right. The 6-inch drill stroke is ideal for industrial applications or projects where larger parts such as 4 x 4 wood beams are common. The extra stroke length means you can drill deeper without having to make additional holes on the other side to connect, and the 18-inch swing lets you tackle even very large materials.

Drilling through metal is a different experience than working with woods or plastics. Since metal densities vary, you need a drill press that is highly adaptable for different types of metal. The DEWALT DWE1622k Magnetic Drill Press specializes in drilling through steel or similar metals with a two-speed, 10-amp motor and 4-inch drill travel. Its magnetic base lets you position the tool on any ferrous material that's at least 1/2-inch thick. The maximum size bit the tool can accept is 2 inches in diameter.

The press has overload protection electronics that prevent motor burnout and extend the life of the tool. It includes a coolant tank that you can position as needed while you work. The lower speed setting revs up to 300 rpm, and the higher setting is up to 450 rpm, allowing you to easily penetrate even very hard metals. At 35 pounds, the drill press is fairly heavy, but it’s a sturdy, powerful tool.

What to Look for in a Drill Press

Swing

The swing of a drill press is the measurement in inches from the chuck—the clamp that holds the bit in place—to the column, which is the thick metal pole supporting the drill press head, multiplied by two. So if the measurement from your drill press’s chuck to column is 5 inches, then the drill press has a 10-inch swing. Swing tells you the largest piece of wood or metal the drill press can accommodate while drilling a hole right in the center. The larger the swing, the larger materials a drill press can handle, so keep this in mind if you regularly work with big pieces of wood or metal.

Stroke Distance

Also called spindle travel or quill travel, the stroke distance is a measurement of how deep a hole the drill press can create without having to stop and readjust the drill press table or the material being drilled. Smaller or less expensive drill presses often have a mere 2.5-inch stroke distance, sometimes even a little less. Large, heavy-duty floor-standing drill presses can have as much as 6 or more inches of stroke distance, but most hobbyists or general DIYers won’t require this level of performance. As a general rule, around 4 inches of spindle travel is more than sufficient for most typical tasks.

Floor or Benchtop Design

There are two basic styles of drill press: floor and benchtop.

As the name suggests, floor drill presses are large tools that stand on the floor. These have a lot of power and typically a swing between 13 and 20 inches. Floor-standing drill presses are best for professional or heavy-duty use.

Benchtop drill presses sit on a workbench. These smaller machines generally have a swing between 8 and 12 inches, and handle light-to-moderate drilling tasks. Generally, these are the best choice for the average DIYer or hobbyist.

FAQs

What else can you use a drill press for besides drilling holes?

While the primary use of a drill press is to drill holes—particularly large-bore holes or holes that don’t go all the way through the wood—the tool has other uses, as well. With the right bit or attachment, your drill press can also be used to sand or clean wood and metal, drill square holes, deburr wood or metal, and polish or buff wood or metal surfaces.

Can I use the same bits in my drill press and handheld power drill?

As a general rule, as long as the shank size of the bit is not larger than your drill press’s chuck—the most common chuck size for a typical benchtop drill press is ½-inch—you can use the same bits with your drill press as you do with your corded or cordless power drill. Drill presses can handle larger diameter bits than the average power drill, however, which is one of the main benefits of these powerful tools.

Is there any way to use a regular drill in place of a drill press?

If you only need the precision of a drill press for one particular project, you might not want to invest in an entire tool just for that purpose. You can achieve similar results, however, as long as you don’t plan on drilling very large holes or into an exceptionally hard material, by using a frame designed to hold a corded or cordless drill in place as you use it. These frames rotate so you can position the drill just as you need it, and hold it far stiller during use than you’d be able to manage with your hand alone.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was written by Michelle Ullman, the tool expert for The Spruce. She has extensive experience not only in writing about all things related to the home, but also in carrying out various DIY projects, including landscaping, painting, flooring, wallpapering, furniture makeovers, and simple repairs.

item.title: The 8 Best Upright and Canister Vacuums of 2021
item.description: There are two main types of vacuums—upright and canister—they vary based on maneuverability and ease of use. We researched the top vacuum options for you.
item.content:encoded:
Upright vacuums and their canister counterparts are some of the most common and popular varieties of vacuum cleaners on the market. And it's easy to see why: Where the former tend to be workhorses with plenty of versatile attachments, the latter are nimble, lighter weight, and easy to use all around the house.

Both types are so enticing that it can be difficult to decide which one is right for you and your cleaning needs. That's why we've rounded up the best upright and canister vacuums all in one place—read on to learn more about our top picks and to find out which one is right for your cleaning needs and budget.

Here, the best canister and upright vacuums available on the market.

This surprisingly lightweight vacuum from Shark exemplifies so much of what we love about upright vacuums. It features powerful suction, multi-surface cleaning, a hefty dust cup, and anti-allergen technology. Its swivel steering makes it easy to maneuver around the house and clean tight corners. Its LED headlights reveal overlooked debris. But this model does more than check the essential boxes.

This vacuum is actually a two-for-one deal: In addition to its regular upright mode, the main pod lifts away for handheld use on stairs, in hard-to-reach places, or on high-up fixtures like drapes. The crevice tool and upholstery brush attachments clean where neither the upright nor the pod can reach. In sum, if you want to clean your home's floors, furniture, and stairs with one high-quality machine, this Shark upright vacuum should be your pick.

When it comes to both power and quality, Miele’s Compact C1 Pure Suction vacuum cleaner has all the essentials to tackle carpeting and smooth flooring alike. Switch seamlessly between these surfaces with the push of a switch to experience the power of the robust Vortex Motor System in action. Combined with a powerful, six setting motor, and you’re guaranteed an unmatched clean compared to other models.

Intimidated by the strong suctioning and cleaning qualities? There's no need to be! The 13.8 pound wand moves effortlessly around an impressive cleaning radius of up to 29.5 inches. While doing so, it captures up to 99.9 percent of all air particles, so you can ensure your cleaning spree is a safe one.

The strong suctioning qualities and lightweight make-up are overall impressive, while the quiet operation makes it a great choice for families with small children or for those who live in a small apartment. After a few uses, it will become evident why this little “work horse” is an overall favorite.

This upright model from Bissell proves that you don't have to sacrifice quality while saving money on a vacuum. With powerful suction, five height settings, dual-edge cleaning, and multi-level filtration, this vacuum cleans better on the first pass than models of similar prices do after multiple turns around room. The 25-foot power cord, and scatter-proof brush bar makes this machine all the more efficient.

The Bissell CleanView Plus comes with a crevice tool, dusting brush, extension wand, and TurboBrush (which is especially good for cleaning carpets and upholstery). For such a heavy duty machine, it's lightweight and handles easily. If you're cleaning on a budget, this is simply the best upright vacuum for your money.

This Bissell canister vacuum can switch from cleaning carpets to hard floors on a dime, reaches inaccessible nooks and crannies around the house, and seals dirt and debris into its 2.5 liter dust bag. You can adjust the suction to fit your current cleanup job and enjoy hassle-free storage thanks its automatically rewinding power cord.

This model can clean high and low with its telescoping wand and, at only 7.5 pounds, it won't give your arms too much of a workout. This is a wonderful, wallet-friendly option for anyone who wants a nimble little vacuum that can handle small cleanups and major messes alike.

This vacuum features some of the most innovative technology on the market at the moment, including a dual-action roller for far-reaching, consistent suction and self-cleaning brushroll that resists even the most matted messes of pet hair. The Vertex deeply cleans carpets of dust, dander, and other allergens, trapping them away in a sealed HEPA filtration system. The only way dirt gets out of this vacuum is by way of its one-button emptying feature.

The attachable pet power brush and crevice tool come in handy when cleaning upholster and hard-to-reach areas. Weighing slightly over 16 pounds, this model is undeniably on the heavier side, but the lift-away pod allows for a lighter-weight cleaning experience, for when you need to clean under furniture or above the floor. The 30-foot power cord lets you coast around an entire room without having to relocate the plug. Finally, with its sleek design and rose gold finish, this vacuum matches its performance with its looks.

Dyson received the highest score among canister vacuums in the J.D. Power 2017 Vacuum Satisfaction Studies, so it’s no surprise that their model, the Dyson Cinetic Big Ball Animal Canister Vacuum, gets our vote in the Best High End Canister category. With the ability to clean any floor without frequent canister emptying, this sleek choice is an effective option for your home. This vacuum promises to never lose its suction, and, unlike many other models, there's no need to wash or replace a filter. While it operates, the head sucks up dirt in tricky to navigate spots. When it does meet its .42 gallon capacity, you can eject the contents with the simple tap of a button.

While the initial price upfront is steep, Dyson includes includes a five-year protection plan, so no additional warranty is needed. And, frankly, its enduring performance make it an undeniably solid investment.

The key to completely clean hardwood floors is a vacuum that doesn't have a coarse brushroll. While this feature is a perk when dredging up debris from high-pile carpet, it will only get in the way (and even put your floors at risk of getting damaged) when cleaning harder surfaces. Luckily, this upright vacuum from Shark features a brushroll that can be raised or lowered, depending on the type of floor you're currently cleaning.

In addition to its hardwood-friendly brushroll, the Shark Navigator's pet power brush and crevice attachments can pick up dirt, dust, and pet dander with ease, while its lift-away pod makes it easy to clean staircases. If your home is mostly hardwood—but also plagued by everyday messes on upholstery and in hard-to-reach areas—this vacuum is versatile enough to meet all your cleaning needs.

Don't let its overall cleaning power fool you—this canister vacuum is surprisingly gentle on hardwood surfaces. That's thanks, in part, to its adjustable suction controls (which you can access from the wand's handle), but its smaller design details, like the rubber wheels with felt treads, also keep hard floors clean and scratch-free.

If your home's floors are a mix of hardwood and carpet, this canister model is great option for your cleaning needs. In addition to its hardwood-compatible floorhead, it comes with another floor attachment made specifically for low-pile carpets. For multi-surface cleanups, the Bissell Hard Floor Expert Deluxe Canister Vacuum will certainly get the job done.

What to Look for in an Upright or Canister Vacuum

Maneuverability

When shopping for an upright or canister vacuum, consider how easy it'll be to move it from room to room. While upright vacuums glide on built-in wheels and pack a little more suction power, you'll have more weight to push around. Canister vacuums, on the other hand, are lighter, but you might need to carry them since not all models have wheels. Canister vacuums are also usually equipped with longer hoses and wand attachments to reach high, dusty spots like shelves, drapes, and more. 

Dust and debris collection

All the dust and debris you suction up through the vacuum cleaner must go somewhere, so you’ll need to decide whether you want a bagged or bagless model. Both upright and canister vacuums options are available with conventional vacuum cleaner bags, but it should be noted that the trend is towards bagless vacuum cleaners with dust cups that can be emptied and don’t need frequent replacement. While vacuum bags seal in dust and dirt better, it's an extra recurring expense you’ll need to consider.

Filtration

Just about all vacuums have some type of dust filtration, but if you’re looking for enhanced dust, dander, and allergen filtration, consider a vacuum with specialized filtration. Onboard HEPA filters will trap particles as small as 0.03 microns in size, and some models pair these filters with carbon filters for extra odor and dust control. Some filters are washable, while others will need to be replaced on an ongoing basis for long-term effectiveness.

FAQS

When should I choose a canister vacuum over an upright model?

If you plant to use your vacuum on multiple levels of your home, or if you live in an apartment or smaller space, you may be better off choosing a canister over an upright vacuum. Canister vacuums are generally lighter and easier to maneuver from room to room (or from floor to floor), and can reach above-floor areas with more easily than uprights. This makes them extremely versatile cleaning machines that, as long as you don't have high-pile carpets or large rooms to clean, can vacuum your whole home without issues.

When should I choose an upright vacuum over a canister model?

If you're looking for a vacuum with maximum suction power, an upright is the right model for you. This type of vacuum is considered the workhorse of the vacuum family for a reason—upright vacuums are sturdy, usually hold more dirt than other vacuum varieties, and can clean rugs as effectively as bare floors. Homes with carpeted rooms will benefit immensely from an upright vacuum. This model is also a great pick for homes with limited storage space, as it tends to have a smaller footprint than canister vacuums.

What kind of suction power can I expect from upright and canister vacuums?

As mentioned above, an upright vacuum will more than likely have stronger suction than a canister. However, you can find plenty of suction power in both varieties. To get a better idea of your vacuum's suction, take note of how many interior fans it features, the size of its motor, and what it promises in terms of airflow.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was written by Sara Coughlin, a freelance writer and The Spruce’s small appliances expert. From canister models to dustbusters, she’s researched what it takes for a vacuum to stand out in a vast and broad market—and what to look for in up-and-coming models.
item.dc:creator: The Spruce Editors

item.title: The 9 Best Shark Vacuums of 2021
item.description: Shark is one of the most well-known brands when it comes to household cleaning machines. We researched and tested their best-selling models to find the best one.
item.content:encoded:
There's a reason why Shark brand vacuum cleaners make frequent appearances on The Spruce's best lists—with their dependable suction and performance, intentional designs, and ease of use, they're some of the most accessible and satisfying vacuums on the market. If you happen to be a Shark loyalist, we can hardly blame you.

Of course, the selection of Shark vacuums to choose from is only getting wider. And if you aren't totally sure which one is the right choice for your household (and the kind of messes it tends to accumulate), it's easy to feel overwhelmed. That's why we've pored over the current options at Shark and selected our favorites in nine different categories. Whether you want a powerhouse that handles all surfaces or a nimble stick vacuum to tackle quick clean-ups, there's a Shark out there for you.

Here, find our picks for Shark's best vacuum cleaners.

When it comes to getting a clean home, the Shark Navigator Professional NV356E is our top choice. With lift-away technology and a brushroll shutoff, this is a practical choice for hardwood floors or any solid surface floor cleaning, as well as carpets.

The Shark Navigator NV356E has a bristle brush that will agitate carpet fibers to remove deep-seated dirt but can be deactivated to protect hardwood floors from scratches and wear. But what really sets apart this Shark vacuum for hardwood floors is the included Dust-Away attachment with a microfiber pad. When using the Lift-Away vacuum in canister mode, simply attach the Dust Away tool, which is essentially a large microfiber pad that will pick up fine dirt and dust from hardwoods, tiles, and more. People that have actually used the Dust-Away attachment say that combining suction with the microfiber pad means the vacuum will suck up larger items in its path while sweeping up dust and fine particles with the pad’s surface.

The biggest complaint about the Shark Navigator Professional NV356E is that the floorhead isn’t as wide as some other models. The cleaning path is only 9.5 inches wide. However, the dust cup is an impressive 2.2 dry quarts so you won’t need to make frequent trips to empty this vacuum during cleaning sessions.

If you have pets, you likely have an ongoing battle to keep fur and dander under control. The Shark Rotator TruePet NV752 is a popular choice when shopping for a Shark vacuum for pets.

Built on the popular Rotator model upright vacuum that many love for its deep cleaning and lift-away functionality, the TruePet model from Shark incorporates a motorized brush and pet multi-tool. The result is a powerful vacuum with sustained suction that can be used to eliminate pet hair buried deep in carpets, stuck between seat cushions, or clinging to drapes.

Instead of sticking a flimsy attachment on the vacuum’s hose and hoping that you’ll be able to suction the pet hair stuck to your sofa, the Rotator True Pet allows you to attach a motorized brush to the hose and take the lift-away canister with you wherever pet hair lurks. Conquer those pet fuzzies under the bed or on your favorite chair with high-powered bristle action and powerful suction.

In addition, pet owners and allergy sufferers alike will appreciate the fact that this model of Shark vacuum also features a sealed air system and a HEPA filter to trap up to 99.9 percent of allergens. People that have used the Shark NV752 say that it’s definitely the way to go for pet-friendly homes and rave about the agitation and power of the motorized brush in comparison to other vacuums for pet hair that use turbine technology or suction alone to remove fur.

With this advanced model, Shark has outdone itself: The self-cleaning brushroll is an improved version of previous designs, made to pick up even more pet hair with a single pass without the risk of hair wrap. The DuoClean system features silicone fins that maintain constant contact with the floor (even when transitioning from carpets to hard wood) and a soft roller that pulls in small and large debris to a more efficient extent than the original iteration of Shark's DuoClean technology. The LED-lit nozzle makes it easy to see exactly where to go to get every last bit of dirt and the 30-foot cord is long enough that you can coast across a room without having to move where you're plugged in.

The dusting brush, pet crevice tool, and self-cleaning pet power brush handle messes in small spaces and on furniture—and the HEPA filter and anti-allergen complete seal ensures that the dust and dander that they bring in stay trapped. The lift away pod, meanwhile, allows you to clean high up or under furniture without worrying about lugging the whole vacuum along with you (which, at 16 pounds, is on the heavier side).

In short, this model melds what you love about Shark vacuums with minor—but meaningful—upgrades, making it well worth its price.

If you’re looking for a technologically advanced vacuum cleaner with powerful suction, we recommend the Shark Apex Upright Vacuum. It will not only clean your room, but it will also clean itself! Armed with a self-cleaning brushroll for nonstop hair removal, this vacuum is one of the most efficient products Shark has to offer. 

The Apex is easy to assemble and features Shark DuoClean, Powered Lift-Away, and Zero-M technologies. In addition to its advanced design, this product sports a detachable canister that extends the reach of the cleaner head, making hard-to-reach messes a thing of the past. The Apex’s quiet sound design and performance on various surfaces—hardwood floors, carpet, even upholstered furniture—makes it suitable for cleaning just about any room of the house. Furthermore, the product’s advanced anti-allergen complete seal technology and HEPA filter add to its overall efficiency.

If you want to vacuum without wrangling a cord, a battery-operated model is the best choice for you. Perfect for quick pick-ups or small spaces, the Shark Freestyle Cordless Stick Vacuum is a nimble, cost-effective choice.

The Freestyle is powered by a rechargeable battery that offers run times up to about 20 minutes, based on whether you are running it on high or low power. Note that this isn’t a lithium-ion battery, which makes this Shark vacuum lag slightly behind the competition in the cordless vacuum segment. However, it is affordable and the charging station is integrated into a handy storage dock for the vacuum.

This cordless vacuum by Shark might struggle to pick up cereal or larger debris. Even still, this vacuum makes it so much easier to vacuum high-traffic areas frequently or keep up in between deep cleaning sessions. If you’re looking for a light-duty vacuum with no cord hassle from Shark, the Freestyle Cordless Stick Vacuum fits the bill.

Stick vacuums are a great buy for any busy household. They do a solid job at cleaning up everyday messes without the need of lugging out the big guns. While cordless options can seem like a smart purchase—they often have a short battery life which can leave you high and dry when you need it.

This new model has the ability to clean floors but it can also be broken down into a handheld version to tackle stairs, furniture, upholstery, and such. The best feature of this stick vacuum is the self-cleaning brushroll technology that eliminates the need to physically remove wrapped around hairs.

Conquer carpet with a Shark vacuum that is up to the task, thanks to powerful suction and a deep agitating brushroll. The Shark Rotator Professional NV501 is a popular choice among people that have carpeted surfaces to clean and want the versatility and convenience of a Shark vacuum.

Equipped with a wider floorhead than the Navigator line of vacuums, the Rotator Professional will give you a wider cleaning path—which means less effort on your part to clean the floors. The advanced swivel steering built into the Rotator Professional vacuums makes it easier to maneuver, which is a plus since this vacuum weighs 15.5 pounds.

Under the floorhead is the key to the Rotator’s carpet cleaning abilities. Plenty of suction power combines with a bristled brush to extract dirt and debris from its hiding place in your carpeting and area rugs. This model of Shark vacuum is the perfect partner in marathon vacuuming sessions, thanks to its strong suction and impressive cord length.

This stick vacuum is a corded model—meaning you will have to plug it in for operation. However, you don’t have to worry about charging batteries and finishing the job before the juice runs out. This vacuum is super lightweight and weighs only 7.6 pounds. The detachable hand vacuum weighs only 4.6 pounds and is perfect for tackling small jobs and tight spaces—like under the couch cushions or the seats of your car.

The Rocket also comes with a crevice tool, upholstery tool, dusting brush, and a Hard Floor Hero—which is perfect for use on solid flooring that needs a touch-up. There is only room to attach two of the three smaller attachments (crevice tool, upholstery tool, and dust brush), which can be an inconvenience if you think you’ll misplace the loose attachment. One other thing to note is that this 2-in-1 model of Shark vacuum has a rather small dust cup at just .42 dry quarts.

This is a great Shark vacuum to consider if you are debating between a Shark hand vac and stick vacuum. With the Shark Rocket DuoClean, you’ll have easy access to a larger corded stick vacuum for cleaning more square footage along with the convenience of a smaller hand vacuum for quick jobs.

This robotic model makes whole-home cleaning about as hands-off as it can get. Featuring home mapping technology, customizable room selection, a base for self-emptying, and the option to enable voice control through Amazon Alexa, the Shark IQ Self-Empty XL handles the grunt work of vacuuming easily and efficiently. If its battery gets low in the middle of a job, it will return to its charging base and resume cleaning after refueling.

For all its tech-savvy capabilities, this vacuum doesn't skimp on pure cleaning power. The self-cleaning brushroll is designed to remove pet hair without tangling and the suction is powerful enough to extract debris of all sizes across floor surfaces. Plus, the spinning side brushes make sure even tight corners and spaces under cabinets get cleaned.

What to Look for in a Shark Vacuum

Type

From full-sized vacuums to stick and handheld versions, there’s a Shark vacuum to get any job done. The question is what kind of job do you want to get done most often. The size of your home, as well as the types of flooring you have, should drive your choices. 

Feel

Shark vacuums come in various weights and with varying capabilities. While heavier models may do more heavy-duty cleaning, if you’re going to have to haul a vacuum up and down stairs frequently, then you may want to consider lighter models. Also, consider how easy one is to maneuver, particularly if you want to get into tight spots and corners. 

Features

Do you want a cordless vacuum? One that also has a light so you can see in the dark spots? Or perhaps you want one that means you never have to remove those wrapped-around hairs from the vacuum's brushes? Shark makes models with all these features and more. The type of flooring you have as well as how often you use your vacuum should dictate your choices.

FAQs

How do I clean a Shark vacuum?

You'll need to refer to your model's manual to know exactly how to clean it. But, in general, you should empty the dust cup into the trash, using the model's bottom release button, then wipe out the vacuum's interior with a dry microfiber cloth.

How do I clean a Shark vacuum filter?

Most Shark vacuums have reusable filters that you can rinse under water (without soap). They'll need at 24 hours to air dry completely, after which you can reinstall them. You'll know the filters are due for a cleaning when the vacuum's airflow or suction decreases. All that said, read your Shark vacuum's manual beforehand, to make sure your particular model has a rinsable filter.

How long do Shark vacuums last?

Shark products purchased from authorized retailers come with a warranty ranging from one to seven years, which covers repairs and replacements for defective parts. Taking advantage of this warranty will help keep your model in shape for longer. More generally, you can expect your vacuum to last for about eight years, depending on how much you use it and what you do to maintain its performance.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was written by Sara Coughlin, a freelance writer and The Spruce’s small appliances expert. From canister models to dustbusters, she’s researched what it takes for a vacuum to stand out in a vast and broad market—and what to look for in up-and-coming models.

item.title: How to Get Your Houseplants Ready to Go Outdoors
item.description: Follow these tips from the Houseplant Guru, Lisa Eldred Steinkop, to get your houseplants ready to live outdoors for the summer.
item.content:encoded:
As we near the last frost date for most of the U.S., it's time to start the annual houseplant migration. Like many houseplant parents, I like to move my tropicals outdoors to enjoy the extra light, air and humidity. However, it's not as simple as just popping them outside when it's warm enough. Lisa Eldred Steinkop, the author of Houseplant Party and founder of The Houseplant Guru, shares her expert tips on how to get your houseplants ready to go outdoors.

Wait Until After the Last Frost Date

I live in the deep south. We have days during the winter when you get spring-like temperatures. Sometimes, it gets tempting to throw caution to the wind and put the houseplants outdoors before the last frost date. Don't do it—they are tropical species. Even early spring temperatures may be too cold for their liking. When in doubt, wait until the overnight temperatures are well into the upper 50s or 60s, and there is no chance for a surprise frost or freeze.

Repot

"If you are moving them out for the summer, you may want to up-pot them into larger pots if they need it before moving outside or right when you do so the mess is outside," suggests Steinkop, "Especially if they are rootbound because they usually need more water outside and rootbound plants would need even more."

Believe it or not, your potted plants still grew while indoors, and you probably didn't repot them during the growing season. Spring is the perfect time to refresh the soil and give them a nice new roomy pot to grow in.

Getting the Plants Acclimated

"Plants inside do not have as much protection on their leaves as they do when they are outside, says Steinkop, "They don't need it because they are trying to gather as much light as they can in our lower light homes." Consequently, an indoor plant needs to build up a thicker layer (cuticle) on their leaves before sun exposure, so they do not get a sunburn (yes, plants can get burned). "That is why plants should never be taken outside and immediately plopped in the sun," warns Steinkop.

How do you acclimate plants? "Put them on the north side of the house in the shade or under a tree for a couple of weeks to get it used to being outside," Steinkop explains, "Then move it gradually into the sun," She says it's comparable to going to the tanning booth a few times before you head to the beach so you don't get a sunburn from the sudden, intense exposure to the sun.

Also, protect them from the wind because the plants are not used to air movement, and the wind could stress them out and even damage them. "This acclimation process pertains to all plants, including cacti and other succulents," says Steinkop.

Not All Houseplants Should Summer Outdoors

Not all plants take well to the change in environment, even when you do it gradually. The most significant stressor is sunburn. "If they are not acclimated, they will sunburn, and with thinner leaved plants, it may be shocking enough to kill them," explains Steinkop.

Sunburned plants will wilt excessively or develop brown patches on their leaves. Research your plant before placing it outside to make sure you truly understand its light needs. Ambient light in a shaded outdoor environment is much brighter than many indoor areas.

"Some plants would rather not be in the full sun outside," says Steinkop. "High light plants are fine, but if you have a medium to low-light plant, such as an aspidistra, fern, or aglaonema, they will prefer to be in a shaded spot outside. Make sure the final location you want to place them out is a safe place for them."

Prevent Hitchhikers

Being outdoors means there's a chance for insects and other pests to reside in your potted plants. To help limit the chance for hitchhikers, use risers underneath your plants, so they do not sit directly on the ground. "This keeps the drainage hole off the ground and not only helps with drainage but will help keep insects, worms, centipedes and mollusks (roly polies) out of your plants," explains Steinkop.

Check Moisture Levels Daily

Potted plants in the outdoors will dry out faster. "Remember outside there is wind and more light, so your plants will need to be watered more often," says Steinkop, "Check them daily to see if they need water."

Plants in unglazed pots, like terra cotta, may even require watering every day. Remember to water thoroughly every time to ensure adequate moisture.

item.title: The 6 Best Patio Dining Sets of 2021
item.description: The perfect dining set for your patio should be stylish, durable, and comfortable. We researched the best options in a range of styles and price points.
item.content:encoded:
Whether you live somewhere that's warm all year round or you just want to take advantage of sunny days when you can get them, an outdoor space is a coveted commodity. Turning it into a true oasis requires the right furniture, especially if you plan on using your space for eating or entertaining. Choosing a patio dining set is fun if not a little daunting, as there are a wide range of options out there depending on the size and look you're going for.

Here, we rounded up the best patio dining sets for every budget and style.

Your outdoor space is your personal sanctuary, so it's understandable if you want to invest a bit in certain pieces to make it just right. Take this Frontgate set, which balances style and function for a gorgeous outdoor dining setup.

The seven-piece set includes six chairs and a dining table, so you can sit with multiple guests comfortably. Each chair is crafted of lightweight, powder-coated aluminum and features teak insets on each armrest for an elevated look. The chairs' crisp, white cushions—which are optional—are easy to clean, so you won't have to worry about any stains or spills. The set is complete with the dining table, which features a teak top situated on a powder-coated aluminum base.

Though this set is certainly a splurge, Frontgate offers a 10-year structural warranty on all outdoor aluminum, teak, and wicker furniture frames, as well as a two-year warranty on cushion fabrics, so you can feel confident in your purchase.

Patio dining sets are no small purchase. If you're looking for something that can seat four or more people, most options will start in the $500 range. If that's out of the question for you, that doesn't mean you can't find something—just check out the ASKHOLMEN Table and Chair Set from IKEA.

The budget-friendly set is constructed from durable, sustainably sourced acacia, and you can choose from two wood finishes and an assortment of cushion colors. The 45 x 34.75 x 30-inch patio table can fit four adults comfortably, and if you want to stow the set in a garage or shed once you're done, every piece folds up flat.

Though cast iron has long been popular in outdoor spaces, in recent years cast aluminum has jumped in popularity amongst people looking for new metal furniture. Why? Because cast aluminum is just as durable, lighter weight, and less expensive than cast iron.

This five-piece set melds the best of new and old. With its curved arms and legs and latticework pattern, the design nods to more ornate, traditional cast iron styles and would fit in perfectly on a patio alongside traditional cast iron pieces.

There’s a reason families love sitting at picnic tables in the park: Those long, narrow benches are a flexible-seating secret because they can accommodate quite a few people for a cozy, casual meal. A bench can easily seat four of five squirming children, but won’t seem empty with just two people sitting upon it, and can take up way less space than four or five adult-size chairs. Benches are also a good space-saving option since they aren’t typically as deep as chairs and don’t have backs to worry about.

This bench dining set from Christopher Knight Home is an elevated take on the traditional picnic table with wooden seats and a metal base. It'll look right at home in industrial, modern, and rustic spaces, and gives you plenty of flexibility to play around with colorful throw pillows and decor.

If your outdoor space is limited or you're working with a balcony as opposed to an actual backyard, Hashtag Home's Ainsley 3-Piece Bistro Set will definitely come in handy. The table is large enough to accommodate a few dishes if you're looking to dine al fresco, but at the same time, its small 28 x 23 x 23-inch frame can fit almost anywhere.

If you're looking for a low-maintenance set, this is a great pick. The two chairs feature slats that allow rain to run through them, rather than pool, so you won't have to deal with mold or mildew. The chairs also fold down, so they're easy to store in a garage or shed when not in use. The Hashtag Home set is available in four fun colors: white, black, navy, and red.

Bar height dining sets, where the table and chairs are elevated above the typical dining set, are an increasingly popular option, and for good reason: They work for both intimate dinners and entertaining. With the elevated height, it’s comfortable to stand at the table in addition to sitting, so friendly groups can squeeze in for a conversation. Plus, they have a more casual vibe that's perfect for outdoor areas.

This 5-piece set from AllModern includes four chairs and a table, all of which have sturdy aluminum frames and slatted resin tops that are both UV- and mildew-resistant. If you're worried about the extra height making storage difficult, fear not: The chairs are stackable and easy to take care of during the off-season.

What to Look for in a Patio Dining Set

Size

Finding the right-sized pieces to fit your space is probably the biggest challenge when selecting patio furniture. You want your set to be roomy enough to be comfortable for your family and friends, but not so big that it overwhelms your space. Make sure to measure carefully, incorporating enough room for people to back chairs out and walk around.

Style

Patio furniture comes in a variety of styles, from sleek and modern to homey and rustic and everything in between. Patio furniture should complement your home’s style and any existing outdoor furniture and landscaping, but if you plan to use it frequently and not just look at it, make sure it’s comfortable and functional. 

Material

A patio set's material needs to be compatible with its surrounding space and climate. If your patio furniture will live in an enclosed location or will have plenty of shelter, you may not have to be as selective as you would if your furniture will be in the direct path of the sun, rain, and other elements.
item.dc:creator: Ayn-Monique Klahre

item.title: The 5 Best Beach Chairs of 2021
item.description: Beach chairs can provide a variety of features to help you relax outside. We researched the best beach chairs so you can find the right one.
item.content:encoded:
There’s nothing quite like a relaxing day on the beach, but there’s nothing serene about getting sand, well, everywhere. To keep yourself a little cleaner and a little more comfortable on your day off, you’ll need a quality beach chair. These lightweight outdoor chairs give you a little lift up and offer both back and head support, plus often come with handy extras like cup holders, pockets, and even a place to safely stash your phone or e-reader. Ready for some fun in the sun?

Here, the best beach chairs available online.

There’s no doubt about it: The best beach chair is one that marries both form and function, and this one by RIO doesn’t disappoint. At just eight pounds, the lightweight and rust-proof aluminum frame is far easier to carry than most other beach chairs that tip the scales somewhere between 15 and 20 pounds. The chair also has a very practical flexible suspension design meant to conform to your body to offer the very best in support. Both of these features alone make the chair a great option for anyone, but particularly older adults who can’t lug a hefty chair, but require more support than your standard chair offers.

There are plenty of additional comfort features here, too. The chair has a four-position recline, as well as an adjustable pillow. What’s more, you’ll find a large storage pouch on the back for all of your essentials, plus a cup holder to keep your beverage of choice handy and free from sand. There’s no need to worry about portability, either. When folded, the chair features padded, adjustable straps to make backpack-style transport a breeze.

When it comes to beach chairs, you can be sure Tommy Bahama is going to deliver. The brand was among the first to produce backpack-style chairs, and they’ve truly perfected them. How so? When folded as a backpack, this seven-pound chair is not only easy to carry (thank you, padded and adjustable straps!), but it also functions as, well, a backpack. On the exterior, you’ll find two pockets—one mesh one for gear (think a towel, a wet bathing suit, or even your wallet) and one insulated cooler-style bag for your lunch or beverage of choice. 

This chair delivers in the area of comfort, too. The place to perch easily adjusts to five different seating positions, including a lay-flat option, plus a contoured headrest.

Though technically a camping chair, you can rely on YETI to make a perch suitable for all kinds of outdoor adventures, including the beach. Like all things YETI makes, this chair is extra durable, making it the perfect choice for someone who thinks your typical beach chair is just a little too flimsy. Of course, YETI also excels at creating fantastic beverage accessories, like mugs and coolers, so you can count on this tough-as-nails chair to have an equally reliable cup holder. It isn’t your typical flimsy pocket; it’s a hard-sided cup holder that stays upright even when the chair is folded. The two-tiered cup is just the right size for whatever beverage you prefer, be it cans, longnecks, or even YETI brand vessels like Ramblers, the Colster, wine tumblers, and more.

When it comes to children’s beach chairs, you really can’t beat this option. Though it may not have the visual appeal of the classic beach chair, it’s so much more functional—plus, it’s suitable for a wide range of other outdoor adventures, from camping to sporting events.

Though the chair is a bit of investment compared to the aforementioned classic models, it’s worth it. The chair will grow with your child until they’re ready for an adult beach chair since it’s suitable for babies as young as three months and kids weighing up to 75 pounds. While your little one is still young, the five-point removable harness keeps them nice and secure. Then, as your child grows, the seat morphs to reveal two leg holes perfect for letting baby stand with support. Once your child is a bit bigger, convert the chair back into a regular seat—sans harness. 

Additional included features include a removable snack tray for bites and meals on the go, a sun canopy for extra protection, and a carry bag to make transport a breeze.

If you really want to maximize your beach day as a day of relaxation and TLC, you may want to opt for this chair, as it can easily be converted into a seat that more closely resembles a pool lounger. 

The chair, which sits a comfortable 12 inches off the ground (not too high and not too low), features five adjustable chair positions and three adjustable footrest positions—including one that combines to let you lay flat. For sunbathers, the unique patented design will be what ultimately wins you over: The headrest opens to a face cavity, and the side slits of the chair function as arm slots, so you can comfortably lay flat even when on your stomach.

What to Look for in a Beach Chair

Price

Prices range pretty drastically. In most cases, the cheapest chairs are relatively flimsy and lack extras. That said, there’s really no need to spend at the high end to get a quality beach chair. There are plenty of truly outstanding options right around the $50 mark. 


Portability

Today, many beach chairs come with some sort of strap to make carrying easier (no more stuffing a bulky chair under your arm along with all of your other beach supplies!). That said, not all are created equal. The most basic straps are canvas shoulder straps that hang down under the seat of the chair when in use. The more comfortable straps, though, are backpack-style straps that are padded and can be easily adjusted for proper fit. 


Extra features

You may want to consider whether or not the beach chair you’re selecting has helpful added features that improve functionality. This includes things like multi-position recline, cup holders, sun canopies, storage pockets, and even insulated coolers.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was researched and written by Brigitt Earley, a freelance writer who has spent the last 10-plus years researching the best home goods for various digital publications, including The Spruce and Good Housekeeping. From beach chairs and outdoor tables to throw pillows and space heaters, she’s covered it all. You won’t catch Brigitt at the beach without a Tommy Bahama beach chair.
item.dc:creator: Brigitt Earley

item.title: The 8 Best Cheap Vacuum Cleaners of 2021
item.description: The best cheap vacuums cleaners should be affordable and efficient. We researched the different features of budget vacuum models that can get the job done well.
item.content:encoded:
If your budget, life situation, or cleaning routine doesn’t warrant spending hundreds of dollars on a vacuum cleaner, don’t worry, you can still find a model that will keep your space clean and tidy without destroying your budget. The vacuums below might have a few limitations compared to our overall best vacuum picks, but they will still get the job done and tackle pet hair, dust, and debris, but at a fraction of the cost.

While they won’t last forever, these vacuums will do their jobs for a few years, until you’re in a position to upgrade your machine.

Here, the best budget vacuums on the market right now.

With the Eureka Blaze, you're essentially paying for three cleaning tools in one—at a price that can't be beat. This top-rated budget pick weighs less than 4 pounds and functions as an upright stick vacuum, handheld vacuum, and a stair vacuum. Wherever you take it around the house, it handily picks up pet hair, dust, and small debris. Our reviewer noted that it may struggle to suck up larger debris without clogging while in the upright mode, but the wider mouth on the dust buster insert should solve that issue.

This model comes with a crevice tool and steers on a swivel, allowing it to access nooks and crannies high and low. It works exceedingly well on hardwood, tile, linoleum, and low-pile rugs, but may need multiple passes to remove dirt from fluffy, high-pile carpeting. Whether you're tidying up the staircase or clearing crumbs out of the furniture, this versatile vacuum will get the job done, without leaving a dent in your wallet.

Don’t want to be limited by a power cord as you clean? Then you need a cordless vacuum like the powerful Shark Navigator Freestyle Stick Vacuum. This lightweight design is great for quick cleanup jobs on all types of surfaces, and it has a runtime of around 24 minutes on bare floors and 17 minutes on carpets.

The Shark Navigator needs four hours to charge up the battery, and at 7.5 pounds, it’s light enough to carry all around your home. It offers a two-speed brushroll for carpets and bare floors, and the extra-large dust cup is easy to empty. This stick vacuum excels at picking up pet hair, making it a great investment for pet owners.

Handheld vacuums are ideal for picking up small messes around the house, and one of the top-rated affordable products in this category is the Black+Decker Dustbuster. This compact vacuum weighs just 2 pounds, and its lithium battery provides strong suction and extended runtime.

This handheld vacuum has a larger dust cup, allowing you to collect 50 percent more dirt before you need to empty it, and the washable bowl and filter let you keep the transparent vacuum looking pristine. Its wide mouth is great for picking up large debris—like spilled ingredients in the kitchen—and the vacuum comes with a wall mount so it’s always within reach.

This inexpensive vacuum comes with a crevice tool and brush tool, plus it delivers impressive suction and is easy to clean.

Robotic vacuums can be really expensive—new models often cost close to $1,000! However, you can get the hands-off cleaning abilities of a robot vacuum at an affordable price with the Pure Clean Automatic Robot Vacuum. This affordable model costs is a fraction of the price, and it has all the features you’d expect—and then some.

The Pure Clean Robot Vacuum has a 90-minute run time, and all you have to do to start it is press a button! It works well on tile, hard floors, and short carpets, and it has a built-in cliff sensor that will stop it from falling down stairs. This robot vacuum has a thin 3-inch profile that lets it fit under furniture, and it picks up dirt and dust with its dual rotating brushes. The Pure Clean Robot Vacuum does a great job capturing pet hair and dirt, making it a wonderful option for daily tidying.

If you’re partial to canister vacuums, the Bissell Zing is a budget-friendly option that doesn't skimp on performance. This bagless model uses cyclonic technology to create powerful suction that captures dirt on both carpets and hard floors.

The Bissell Zing weighs less than 8 pounds, making it easy to move around your home. It has a 15-foot retractable power cord, and the large dirt cup is easy to empty with the push of a button. You can alternate between cleaning carpets (even thick, high-pile rugs) and hard floors with the flip of a switch, and the vacuum comes with a crevice tool and dusting brush, as well.

If you have one or more pets, you know how quickly pet hair can take over your home. Regular vacuuming and dusting is a must in pet households, and the Bissell Pet Hair Eraser will be a welcome addition to your cleaning arsenal.

This compact corded hand vacuum is specially designed to tackle pet hair. The rubber nozzle lets you remove more hair from furniture and stairs, and the suction nozzle works wonders on dry messes around the house. Plus, this handheld vacuum has a multi-level filtration system to trap household allergens, and its lightweight design is perfect for cleaning the stairs or even the inside of your car! The rubber nozzle for this vacuum i}s a particularly useful feature, as it scrapes the hair off carpets and furniture with ease.

Allergy sufferers often benefit from using a bagged vacuum, rather than a bagless model, because it ensures that any allergens it sucks up stay sealed away until its bag is safely tossed in the trash. This bagged option from Eureka provides that same sense of security at an approachable price.

In addition to its triple filtration bag system, this model features a highly portable and lightweight design, a deluxe floor brush, a bare floor nozzle, and a blower port that should come in handy when vacuuming the garage or porch. Meanwhile, the included crevice tool and upholstery brush make messes in corners and on furniture easy to access. Irritating dust, dander, and debris won't stand a chance against this mighty little machine.

Not only does the Bissell Featherweight Stick Vacuum come in several stylish colors, it makes cleaning up hard surfaces a snap. It can even clean up minor messes on countertops, thanks to its dust buster attachment.

This vacuum’s dirt tank empties easily and holds up to .6 liters of debris. Its cord wraps tidily around the length of the stick's handle, allowing you to store it without risk of it getting tangled. For quick cleanups on furniture or in small spaces, switch to the crevice tool. The floor nozzle can handle the rest. Behind its flashy color and simple design, Bissell's Featherweight is a highly effective, ultra lightweight vacuum for hard floors—you may never use your broom again.

What to Look for in a Cheap Vacuum Cleaner

Style

If you want robust cleaning power with a wider floorhead and larger dust bin, an inexpensive upright vacuum might be your best bet—however, it's likely to weigh more than other options. There are also more compact canister vacuums, which are great for stairs, and stick vacuums that are lightweight and easily maneuvered. Even robotic vacuums can be found on a budget, so really, no style of vacuum is off the table.

Dust bin and filters

Keep recurring costs low by looking for a budget vacuum with a dust bin instead of bags that need to be replaced. Just make sure that you keep the dust bin clean to prevent a loss of suction power and performance from your vacuum. Washable filters will also reduce ongoing costs since they can be rinsed clean.

Cordless

Are you looking to cut the cord but keep the price tag in check with your next vacuum cleaner? While many budget-friendly vacuums are still corded models, there are some great stick vacuums available that cost less than $100. Just be sure to check the battery life and make sure that it's adequate for your cleaning needs.

FAQs

How often should I replace a vacuum?

Generally, you can expect a vacuum to last for about eight years. Several factors can affect that estimate, including how much you use it, what you do to maintain it, and what style of vacuum it is (for example, a sturdy upright vacuum will likely work for longer than a robotic model). Of course, if your vacuum is on the less expensive side, that may come at the cost of a few additional years of functionality.

How do I clean a vacuum?

Your first step should always be to empty your vacuum, either by throwing away its dust bag or releasing the dust cup into the trash. Next, use a microfiber cloth to wipe any remaining fine debris from the vacuum's interior. Depending on your model, you may be able to wash out the inside with soap and water, and even rinse out the filter. However, some vacuums have replaceable filters or can't get wet at all, so make sure to refer to your vacuum's manual before starting to clean it. Your last step should be checking the wheels and cleaner head for hair wrap. If you do use water to clean your vacuum, let everything air dry before reassembling.

What should I expect from a budget vacuum?

As mentioned earlier, vacuums that are on the more affordable end of the spectrum may lack some of the bells and whistles you'd find on higher-end models, like a wide array of attachments, intensely powerful suction, and a spacious dust cup. There are plenty of vacuums that will cover your essential cleaning needs at an affordable price, but if you're looking for a more specialized machine you may need to look at a higher price point.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was written by Sara Coughlin, a freelance writer and The Spruce’s small appliances expert. From canister models to dustbusters, she’s researched what it takes for a vacuum to stand out in a vast and broad market—and what to look for in up-and-coming models. She personally loves and relies on BLACK+DECKER’s Dusbuster, our pick for best inexpensive handheld, to tackle small messes in her studio apartment.
