item.title: The 8 Best Teeth Whitening Products of 2021
item.description: White teeth can make a person appear younger, more awake, and more put-together. We researched the best products so that you can achieve a whiter smile.
item.content:encoded:
If you're looking to get a brighter smile but don't want to splurge on professional whitening services, there are many over-the-counter options that can offer you comparable results at a lower price. From strips and LED trays to toothpaste and pens, we've researched the best products to whiten your teeth safely and effectively.

Read on for our top picks.

The Brilliant Complete Teeth Whitening System from GLO Science was developed by the celebrity dentist, Dr. Jonathan B. Levine, and it delivers impressive results. The kit includes a LED mouthpiece that connects to a controller, a USB power adapter, ten vials of hydrogen peroxide GLO whitening gel, a tube of lip balm, and a carrying case. The ten vials are supposed to be enough for 40 or more applications, and additional GLO whitening gel can be purchased separately.

After applying the lip balm to your lips and brushing the whitening gel onto your teeth, the LED mouthpiece goes in your mouth. The light activates through the connected controller, which then applies heat and light onto the front of your teeth. Once activated, the LED light will stay on for eight minutes. The teeth whitening system can be used up to four times a day and will typically offer noticeable results within a few days.

A few whitening sessions a day for at least five days in a row is recommended. And overuse shouldn’t be an issue since the kit was designed to eliminate sensitivity. While this system certainly isn’t the cheapest option on the market, it delivers professional-level results. If you’re looking for the best overall teeth whitening product, the GLO Science system is worth splurging on.

Today, many brands offer a version of teeth whitening strips, but Crest has been in the game the longest. Not surprisingly, the toothpaste manufacturer still makes the best strips. While there are a few tiers of Crest Whitestrips currently on the market, the 3D White Professional Effects Whitestrips are the way to go.

Each box includes 20 individual packets of upper and lower strips, which are worn for a half-hour once a day. The no-slip strips stretch and mold to the shape of your teeth. With Crest’s Advanced Seal Technology, you can talk and even drink water while wearing them. And although the strips are notably grippy, they’re easy to remove and don’t leave a sticky residue. Although you can expect to see results within a few days, the full 20 days will provide dramatically whiter teeth.

Not all teeth are created equal, and neither should teeth whitening products. Those with darker, more set-in stains might want to opt for a stronger, more potent whitening formula, while those with sensitive teeth or lighter stains might prefer a gentler approach. And, of course, these needs could change over time—you might need a strong formula only at the beginning, and then rely on something lighter for upkeep.

Glowup is a great solution to these issues, providing LED teeth whitening kits that are tailored to both your short- and long-term needs. When ordering, you'll first take a survey asking you about your brushing habits, sensitivity, and so on. They'll then send you a customized kit with about a week's supply of whitening gels in either a light, medium, or strong formula.

To use, start by drying the front of your teeth, then apply the gel evenly over your teeth and insert the mouthpiece. The LED mouthpiece can be plugged into any smartphone, so it's convenient to use on the go or around your house. Each session lasts about 16 minutes—almost half the time of most whitening strips—and can lighten your teeth up to eight shades after a week of use.

At-home grooming treatments are becoming more and more high-tech, and as a result, many teeth whitening systems include LED lights. But the one that shines brighter than the rest is the Bright On Premium Teeth Whitening Kit from SmileDirectClub.

In addition to a hands-free LED accelerator light, this system comes with a six-month supply of whitening pens. Each pen is filled with an enamel-safe, dentist-approved gel formulated to be effective yet also suitable for even the most sensitive teeth. The LED tray can be plugged into your smartphone, so you can whiten your teeth anywhere you go. For best results, SmileDirect Club suggests daily ten-minute sessions for at least a week.

Whitening toothpaste is an excellent solution for those who want a bright, sparkly smile. If you already brush your teeth twice a day, why not kill two birds with one stone and use a specially formulated whitening toothpaste, like Colgate Optic White Express? It contains hydrogen peroxide, which is the gold standard ingredient for bleaching teeth and is safe for ongoing daily use.

This toothpaste is not only practical but also fast when it comes to whitening teeth. According to Colgate, if you use it twice a day, you’ll have whiter teeth in as little as three days. That being said, you’ll see the best results with continuous use. Colgate Optic White Express also contains fluoride, so it’s the only toothpaste you’ll need to whiten your teeth and prevent cavities.

If you have reusable trays, all you need to whiten your teeth is a highly concentrated gel. Opalescence PF 35% Whitening Gel is the top choice of dentists and becoming quite popular among consumers. A pack includes eight syringes filled with mint-flavored carbamide peroxide, and each syringe contains enough gel for three to four applications. 

Similar to other teeth whitening products, the Opalescence gel is intended to be applied for up to 30 minutes at a time. Since it contains 35 percent of the active ingredient, sessions longer than a half-hour aren’t recommended, especially for those with sensitive teeth.

If sensitivity has prevented you from whitening your teeth in the past, we recommend Lumineux Oral Essentials Whitening Strips. These strips are formulated without hydrogen peroxide, which is typically the culprit when it comes to pain and other sharp sensations.

Unlike many other whitening products, Lumineux Oral Essentials Whitening Strips remove stains with coconut oil, sea salt, sage oil, lemon peel, and other naturally sourced ingredients. Not only are they gentle enough for sensitive teeth, but they’re also safe to use on veneers, crowns, and porcelain caps. Each box comes with 14 treatments, which can be applied up to three times a day for whiter teeth in just a week.

The ON THE GO Teeth Whitening Pen from Go Smile is convenient, compact, and affordable. This whitening pen has a sleek application brush that dispenses pre-filled gel as you twist it, which makes it easy to evenly coat your teeth. The mint-flavored gel is formulated to stick to your teeth better than other whitening pens—a necessary feature for a product that doesn’t have strips or trays to hold it in place.

Since it doesn’t need to be wiped off, the gel contains less hydrogen peroxide than most whitening serums. After applying the gel, wait at least 20 minutes before eating or drinking anything. Using the entire pen is recommended to achieve noticeably whiter teeth, so the results aren’t as quick as other whitening systems. However, the portability and affordability of this pen are what really make it stand out. Throw the Go Smile pen in your purse, toiletry bag, gym bag, car, or desk drawer to whiten your teeth anytime, anywhere.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was researched and edited by Lily Sperry, a lifestyle writer and commerce editor here at The Spruce. When looking for the best teeth whitening products, she consulted dozens of third-party reviews, keeping both affordability and effectiveness in mind. She's a fan of the Glowup Whitening Kit, which was worked well on her sensitive teeth.

item.title: African Violets Shouldn't Be Throw-Away Plants—Here's How to Keep Them Alivethes
item.description: Grab these tips from houseplant pro Darryl Cheng, of House Plant Journal, on how to keep African violets alive and blooming all year long.
item.content:encoded:
I'm an avid fan of African violets. When I first learned about them, I always assumed they were fussy plants that you only purchased for their lovely flowers. Once the flowers dropped, well, you just tossed them. In the past year, I learned they will flower profusely all year long when you provide them with all the appropriate conditions. What does it take to keep them alive and flowering? Houseplant expert Darryl Cheng, the author of The New Plant Parent and creator of House Plant Journal, shares his pro tips on how to keep your African violets looking great!

It's All About the Light

Lighting is the trickiest thing when it comes to growing African violets. They need bright light to bloom but do not tolerate hot, direct sun. How can you tell if your plants are getting enough or too much sunlight? If you notice the leaves are very dark green, and the stems are leggy, it's not getting enough light. If the leaves are light or have beached/white spots, it's getting too much.

"Don't judge your success with these plants based only on how much they bloom," says Cheng, "I derive joy from the overall plant, but if you want maximum blooms, the plant will need to be right on the windowsill of your largest, sunniest window - minimum two or three hours of direct sun."

Suppose you lack the proper natural light, no worries! "I personally don't have windows that give me two to three hours of direct sun," explains Cheng. "I use a powerful grow light kept at about one foot away for 14 hours a day." If using grow lights, make sure you give the plants at least eight hours of darkness too. This helps them produce flowers.

Water Them Correctly

African violets prefer moderately moist soil. "You should watch for the soil to become almost halfway dry before thoroughly watering," says Cheng. "Avoid letting the soil become completely dry, but do not aim to keep the soil soaking wet at all times."

Make sure the water is at room temperature before you water the plants to avoid shocking the roots. Another tip is to allow tap water to sit overnight. This will ensure the chlorine evaporates and the water isn't too cold before you water. This method is also suitable for all your other houseplants.

Some enthusiasts recommend you should never get African violet's leaves wet. This is, in part, because the leaves are susceptible to rot if kept in high humidity. So, it's often advised to water the plants from the bottom to avoid getting excess water on the foliage. As long as use a slender spout watering can to water directly in the soil and the plant has excellent air circulation, the leaves will be fine. 

Feed Them

All plants need food to thrive, and fertilizing your African violets will help them flower. Cheng says that using a fertilizer with a higher phosphorus (P) generally encourages flowering.

"Fertilizer ratios are listed as nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium. A higher P fertilizer will have numbers in the ratio 1-2-1 or even 1-3-1, for example, or 8-14-9," explains Cheng. "Notice the ratios don't have to be exact." As long as the middle number is the highest, that will indicate the fertilizer has a higher phosphorus level.

You can also use a specially formulated liquid African violet fertilizer at one-quarter strength every time you water or at full strength every two weeks during the active growing season (spring and summer). Don't go overboard—over-fertilizing is a more common problem than under-fertilizing.

Repot Correctly

African violets like it snug when it comes to pot size. The pot should only be about one-third to half the diameter of the plant. For example, if your plant is about seven to nine inches wide, the pot only needs to be three inches wide. The proper pot size will promote blooming. Don't go too deep, either. Shallower pots are better for drainage and root aeration.

Finally, only repot the plant in fresh soil once a year and use an African violet potting mix or a well-draining all-purpose potting soil.

Appreciate the Foilage

Even if you can not get your plants to reflower, they make exciting foliage plants. "African violets are interesting plants not just for their flowers," says Cheng, "Their leaves form a beautiful rosette pattern and can be propagated. With excellent light, a whole new plant can develop from one leaf." Keep the foliage looking great by dusting periodically with a small, soft brush.
item.dc:creator: Debbie Wolfe

item.title: How to Grow Hydrangeas
item.description: Hydrangeas (Hydrangea spp.) are usually easy to grow. With myriad varieties and colors of blooms, these shrubs are popular landscaping options.
item.content:encoded:
With dozens of species and even more varieties, hydrangeas (Hydrangea spp.) have been popular garden plants for decades. Their flowers now come in a wide array of colors, including bright blue, deep red, and pale green. Some hydrangeas have large, round flower clusters while others have smaller, flatter, and more delicate flowers. The foliage also varies depending on the species. Plus, these versatile shrubs thrive in sandy coastal soils, shady woodland sites, and almost everything in between. To ensure that hydrangea shrubs have time to establish a healthy root system before blooming, it is best to plant them in fall or early spring. Once planted, hydrangeas are rapid growers, averaging 2 feet or more of growth per year.

Hydrangea Care

Most hydrangeas can adapt to a wide range of growing conditions. They are generally hardy from USDA growing zones 5 to 9. And as long as they are planted in well-draining soil with plenty of organic matter, they should grow well.

Plan to water your hydrangeas regularly, especially in hot and dry weather. And fertilize them once a year. You also might need to do some pruning each year, but it shouldn’t be excessive. 

Light

Too much shade can reduce a hydrangea shrub's flower output. Hydrangeas do well in the partial shade provided by tall deciduous trees, especially if they receive morning sun and the partial shade is in the heat of the afternoon. They will also thrive in full sun but might need extra water on hot summer days.

Soil

In general, hydrangeas can tolerate a wide range of soil types. One of the perks of growing hydrangeas is being able to change their flower color. Although somewhat determined by cultivar, the color can be tweaked by the amount of aluminum in the soil and the soil pH. The soil pH determines how available aluminum is to the plants. Acidic soil (aluminum available to the plants) will give you blue flowers, and alkaline soil (aluminum unavailable to the plants) will give you pink flowers.

To decrease the acidity of your soil and change flowers from blue to pink, add hydrated lime to the soil in the spring. To increase the acidity to change flowers from pink to blue, add aluminum sulfate to your soil in the spring, or mulch with oak-leaf mulch.

Water

Hydrangeas prefer a deep watering at least once a week unless you've had rainfall. During particularly hot weather, slightly increase the amount of water you give your plants, but make sure they're not sitting in soggy soil.

Temperature and Humidity

Hydrangeas prefer fairly mild temperatures. In areas with bitterly cold winters, dieback (a plant dying from the tips of its leaves inward) can be a problem. Protect your hydrangeas from cold winds by planting them in a sheltered spot or with a burlap windscreen or burlap frame filled with dry leaves. A north- or east-facing site, where temperatures remain somewhat constant, is a better choice than a spot on the south and west side of your property, which will heat up in the winter sun and can cause buds to open prematurely and be vulnerable to cold snaps. Furthermore, hydrangeas prefer moderate to high humidity, as dry climates can cause the leaves to wilt.

Fertilizer

If your soil is rich in nutrients, you likely won't have to fertilize your hydrangeas. In fact, if hydrangeas are given too much high-nitrogen fertilizer, they might grow full and lush but with fewer flowers. If your soil is not rich, apply a flowering shrub fertilizer in the spring.

Are Hydrangeas Toxic?

Hydrangeas contain cyanogenic glycosides, which are toxic both to people and animals when ingested. The leaves, buds, and flowers have higher concentrations of this compound. 

Symptoms of Poisoning

Symptoms of toxicity in both people and animals include nausea, vomiting, gastrointestinal upset, diarrhea, and lethargy. If you suspecting poisoning, contact a medical professional as soon as possible.

Hydrangea Varieties

There are two main groups of hydrangeas: plants that bloom on new growth (the current year's stems) and those that bloom on old growth (last year's stems). Some varieties include:

  • Hydrangea macrophylla: Also known as bigleaf hydrangea, this species grows to around 6 to 10 feet tall and wide and has leaves that reach around 6 inches long.
  • Hydrangea arborescens: Known as smooth hydrangea, this shrub reaches around 3 to 5 feet tall and wide and produces white to pink flowers. 
  • Hydrangea quercifolia: Commonly called oakleaf hydrangeas, this plant reaches around 7 feet tall and wide and sports white to purplish-pink flowers. 

Pruning Hydrangeas

Hydrangeas typically need minimal pruning. But if you would like to reduce the size of your plant or prevent it from flopping over too much, you can remove some of the older canes after the flowers fade. This will reduce crowding and encourage new growth.

The exception to this rule is when cold winters kill the tips of the branches. Then, you should prune in the spring, removing the dead wood and cutting back the stems to a healthy set of buds. If you have an established shrub, you can also take out several of the older stems at this time. Just don't remove all the buds, or you will lose your blooms for that season.

item.title: The 10 Best Mulches of 2021
item.description: Mulch is any material that is used to cover the soil, either with a particular purpose or just to beautify the space. We researched the best options for your yard.
item.content:encoded:
Mulch is a great way to take your yard and landscaping from messy to marvelous with minimal time and expense. After taking the time to select the best shrubs, prepare flower beds, and plant seeds in your garden, adding mulch can really take it to the next level.

You should consider the areas that you plan to cover when selecting your mulch, as well as any family members or pets that will be in close contact with the new addition to your landscaping. Certain mulch products are toxic to pets, while others break down quickly. Some mulch options last for multiple years, but some need to be replaced frequently as they are worked into the soil.

Here are the best mulch options for your lawn and garden.

This all-natural hardwood mulch is the perfect balance of value, use, and quality. It is a vibrant brown color naturally through an aging process that doesn’t add any chemicals or dyes. This results in a natural color that won’t fade over time. It is also a finely shredded mulch, resulting in fewer large pieces that can wash away or get into your grass.

For those who prefer a more striking colorized option, Texas Native mulch does come in a black dyed option. The dye is approved by the EPA, environmentally safe, and non-toxic. Either option makes an attractive addition to your garden, yard, or landscaping.

This budget-friendly option comes in a bag that contains two cubic feet of mulch, which is approximately 56.6. liters, and you can choose from three different colors (black, brown, or red). One bag will cover eight square feet when placed three inches deep. This means that a small investment can really go a long way in large areas that need to be covered with mulch. 

It does break down and fade faster than some of its competitors, but if you are looking to upgrade your outdoor space without spending a lot of money, Vigoro mulches will deliver a big bang for your buck. Colorized mulch does fade over time so to maintain the most vibrant looks, you should plan to replace it at least once per season. Keeping water off of the mulch for at least 24 hours after application can help with color retention.

For a long-lasting mulch that will not fade or deteriorate, rubber mulch is the way to go. NuScape brown mulch has the same look as other wood-based mulches but is heavier, more durable, and made of 100 percent recycled rubber. It also provides a bit of bounce, making it a great option for playgrounds or swing sets.

Rubber mulch tends to be more expensive than its all-natural competitors but lasts for much longer. If you want to put down mulch once and enjoy it for years, the NuScape rubber mulch is a product you will love. Just be ready to invest upfront in its higher cost.

Mulch can do wonders to keep weeds at bay in your vegetable garden. It’s important when mulching a vegetable garden to choose a product that is easy to maintain and isn’t too expensive, as you will be turning over your garden at the end of the season.

Long Leaf Pine Straw is a great option because it is inexpensive and allows water to pass through easily to get to your vegetables. You may still get some weeds that pop through, but these can be easily removed by hand when needed. It tends to have fewer potential seeds than similar options, like straw or hay.

Compost is a great way to mulch flower beds since it provides nutrients to the soil and looks neat and attractive as well. This organic option is made with cow manure, alfalfa meal, and pure earthworm castings. Like any mulch, compost helps soil retain moisture and regulate temperature. It also has the added benefit of nutrients for the plants, often resulting in larger, more colorful, more plentiful, and longer-lasting flowers.

If you’re looking for a black mulch that will keep its vibrant shade for a full year, Earthgro by Scotts is a great product. It works just as any other mulch does by locking in moisture, blocking weeds from getting sunlight, and regulating the temperature of the soil underneath.

This mulch is also available in brown and red. For the longest-lasting color, you should make sure that the mulch is dry for at least 24 hours after applying it to your yard. Colored mulch does need to be replaced at the end of the season or more often, depending on how much sun it receives. Harsh sun or extreme weather can cause the color to fade faster.

One of the most important factors when adding anything directly to your lawn is to choose a product that will improve the soil as well as protect it. This is especially true if you are applying it to an area where grass struggles to grow. Scotts Topsoil is a mixture of organic soil and peat moss, which helps build strong roots to your existing grass.

This is a great option to fill in holes or improve bare patches in your lawn. For those beginning a new garden, Scotts Topsoil is the perfect addition to spruce up the area before and during planting. Keep in mind that this topsoil is designed to be used in-ground rather than in containers or raised beds. It does not prohibit the growth of weeds in garden beds.

For contained use, such as in a raised bed, this weed barrier cloth will keep only your desired plants growing strong. You can add another mulch on top if you prefer, providing both weed protection and the attractive clean look of mulch. A mulch barrier works great in an area where you really want to keep weeds at bay.

This mulch acts as a physical barrier between potential weeds growing in the soil and your beautiful garden. You will need to cut spots for your desired plants to grow. Rainwater has a hard time permeating the paper, though, so additional water is necessary to keep your plants healthy and growing. Unlike its plastic counterparts, this biodegradable option breaks down over time and adds nutrients to your soil.

This mulch is made with bark from sustainable pine forests and replicates the look of your house plant and outdoor potted plant soils, just a little bit nicer. These chips are small but more consistent in size and shape than most shredded mulch products. This provides a cohesive look to potted plants, which many plant growers enjoy.

Mulch in potted plants can help keep moisture in and provide shade and protection to the tender roots growing just under the surface. While a bit more expensive than some other mulch options, the Organic Houseplant Mulch is a great option for small-scale use.

After applying grass seed, following up with the GreenView Fairway Formula Seed Success Biodegradable Mulch will protect them as they grow. This paper mulch/fertilizer combo keeps water in, regulates temperature, and stays put thanks to the included tackifier. The fertilizer encourages grass growth in the areas where you apply.

You will need to purchase grass seed separately, which allows you to customize the application to match your existing lawn. All you need to do is water occasionally to keep the mulch in place. As your grass grows, the pellets break down naturally, leaving you with nothing but a lush lawn.

What to Look for in a Mulch

Type

There are two main types of mulch: organic and inorganic. Organic mulch includes anything that is made from a natural material, such as wood, paper, straw, grass clippings, or compost, that will decompose over time. It does not necessarily mean that the material is free of pesticides or chemicals, although some compost may be. Inorganic mulch includes anything made from synthetic materials, such as rubber mulch or plastic weed cloth.

Use

Mulch is used to create a barrier between the soil underneath and the environment. This can help regulate the temperature of the soil and retain moisture, both beneficial to the roots of plants growing in the mulch. It can also prevent weeds from sprouting, as they do not get sufficient sunlight to germinate and grow.

Pet Safety

Not all mulch products are safe for pets. Cocoa shells as mulch, also known as cocoa bean mulch, is toxic to dogs because it contains caffeine and theobromine, two compounds that can make your dog very sick. If you are a pet owner, it’s best to steer clear of these types of mulch completely. Instead, look for a natural alternative that is pet-safe.

FAQs

What is mulch?

Mulch is any material that is used to cover the soil, either with a particular purpose or just to beautify the space. Mulch benefits a garden by retaining moisture, regulating temperature, and suppressing weeds. Depending on the material, it can also decompose and add essential nutrients to the soil.

Mulch can be made from natural materials, such as wood, straw, clippings, compost, or even paper. Called organic mulch, this type of mulch can help the soil quality as well as look great in your garden. You should make sure that your organic mulch does not include seeds that will sprout and work against your hard work.

Inorganic mulch includes types that are made of synthetic materials, such as rubber pellets or plastic weed sheets. This type of mulch is often more expensive to set up but can last for a long time and look great. It also does not break down over time. This can be a pro or a con, depending on your reason for laying mulch.

When is the best time to mulch?

The top mulch time is mid Spring after the soil has started to warm and before the weeds start rearing their little buds. If you mulch too early, it will prevent the soil from warming and make it harder for your garden to grow in late Spring and Summer. Waiting too long to mulch will mean that you have extra work to do to clear out any weeds that have already started to grow.

Fall is another great time to mulch your garden, especially if you are using organic mulch to improve your soil quality. Mulching in the fall insulates your soil during the colder winter months. Some plants need the cold weather to go dormant, so waiting until the first frost can be a great way to both support your plants and have time to get the mulch down before the cold days and nights of winter.

Can you use old mulch?

Organic mulch is made to break down and provide additional nutrients to the soil as it decomposes. This means that as your mulch ages, it may not function very well as a mulch. If you scoop up a handful of mulch and it looks and feels more like soil, it is time to replace the mulch. Simply work it into the soil to add nutrients and replace it with a new layer.

If the mulch still provides cover, you can reuse it for another season. Rake it to one side as you tend to the soil underneath. This is especially important in vegetable, herb, and fruit gardens where you plan to grow plants to eat. Test your soil, add any nutrients it needs, then rake the mulch back over to cover.

The one exception to this is when your plants or garden experienced disease that you think is tied to the mulch. In this case, you should remove and dispose of the mulch safely. You will need to add a new layer of mulch to cover your soil before the growing season begins.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was researched and written by Katie Begley, who has used mulch to spruce up her yard and benefit her garden in California, Hawaii, Virginia, and North Carolina. Texas Native is her go-to choice after testing out multiple options as she moved around the United States. She is always looking for the best value and performance to enhance her outdoor space.

item.title: The 8 Best Upright Freezers of 2021
item.description: The best upright freezers allow you to store extra food safely. We researched the best ones so you can choose the perfect freezer for your home.
item.content:encoded:
If your freezer is packed to the brim and quickly becoming a jigsaw puzzle, then you may be in the market for an upright model that offers additional space—and, inevitably, a sense of relief. This type of freezer certainly is a game-changer, as it can be set up in your kitchen—where you can easily access your chicken and sweet potato fries at dinner time—or in your garage. They come with double doors or in extra-large capacities, so you can easily peruse what you have and not buy the same item twice at the grocery store.

Upright freezers are in the business of being reliable and practical like your home appliances should be. However, they take it to the next level by delivering space and even the ability to keep your goods frozen for multiple days in the event of a power outage.

Below, the best upright freezers on the market:

This pick from Frigidaire gives you plenty of room to store everything you need, and makes sure it stays frozen solid, thanks to the brand's EvenTemp Cooling System. This technology circulates air to prevent warm spots from forming and ultimately spoiling your food. It's one of many features this upright freezer has that makes it the best option to shop, hands-down.

In addition to the cooling technology, this model also can keep your food frozen for up to two days in the event of a power outage and be installed in a garage. It can withstand temperatures from 0 to 110 degrees Fahrenheit, and even sports a reversible door so you can shimmy it into any spot that's most convenient for you. A design that's both thoughtful and accessible continues within the 15.5-cubic-foot interior, that's outfitted with four shelves and a sliding storage basket. For any items that don't easily stack on shelves, or you'd like to be able to reach for quickly (like a container of ice cream), there are five spacious door bins as well.

Other helpful features include an alarm that sounds if the door is left open, a light at the bottom that tells you at a glance if the freezer is working properly, and LED interior lights so you can see what you're looking for. All in all, this upright freezer checks off all the boxes and would be a great buy for any household.

Don’t burn up cash shopping for an ice-cold appliance. Instead, save money with this budget-friendly freezer from Maytag. It'll treat you to high-end amenities such as interior LED lighting, an automatic defroster, and a fairly large capacity of 15.7 cubic feet. It skips out on a stylish, stainless steel finish, but definitely provides a lot of bang for your buck otherwise.

With its FastFreeze feature, you're able to freeze a large amount of goods very quickly so that they don't lose any of their original, store-bought freshness. This feature typically lasts for 24 hours, before the freezer goes back to its automatic cycle. For those who like to freeze fruit for smoothies or freeze meat, this feature will make a big impact and ensure that every meal with flavor. If you're someone who's looking for an upright freezer for extra storage purposes, this model also comes with three adjustable shelves and a built-in storage gate that turns the freezer floor into usable space.

For a model with a average amount of capacity and a reversible door as well, this piece is sort of a hidden gem. It may use up the same amount of energy as an upright freezer with slightly more space, but will save you money the day you purchase it without a doubt.

For the maximum in upright freezer storage space, turn to this very large option from GE. It's impressive in size, measuring 6 feet and 3 inches tall, and packing in just over 21 cubic feet of space. In comparison, most upright freezers top out at about 20 cubic feet. GE squeezed in an extra 1.3 cubic feet for you to stash a few more steaks or frozen dinners.

This model of upright freezer from GE has four wire shelves and one wire basket to keep things sorted and visible. In addition, four door shelves keep any smaller items in plain sight. Now, the super strong seal of this model may make the door a little tough to open. However, this seal will ensure that no cold air escapes the interior, stabilizing the environment your food is in.

Of course, such a large capacity upright freezer might not fit well in your kitchen, or you may not want to haul this heavy-duty model down to the basement. If you plan to keep it in your garage, know that it will perform well in temperatures from 0 to 110 degrees Fahrenheit, according to the manufacturer. This is also a frost-free unit at a quality price, so you won’t need to worry about thawing and draining this mammoth appliance.

It's quite possible that you don't need a ton of extra freezer space, and are looking for a more compact pick like the Magic Chef MCUF3W2. This upright freezer has just 3.0 cubic feet of storage space, which is ideal for smaller households, apartments, or RVs. Although it does require you to manually defrost it from time to time, it has two wire shelves for organizing easy-to-make meals, meats, fruits, or vegetables. In addition, its reversible door with a recessed handle makes it a flexible option that can be installed just about anywhere.

You can pair it with a matching mini refrigerator to complete an on-the-go kitchen, or set it up in a basement where you're putting together an at-home bar. Once you install it, just use the manual controls to adjust the interior's temperature anywhere between -4 and 6.8 degrees Fahrenheit. This range is much narrower than other models' on the market, but you'll likely find it meets your needs.

Do you keep your upright freezer in the garage? If so, consider this model that is built to be durable and portable, making it the perfect choice for an appliance that will be stored in flexible temperatures.

The Gladiator GAFZ30FDGB features a black matte finish and a unique step-to-open door. It's super convenient to open up the unit using the stainless steel foot pedal when you have arms full of groceries ready to be stocked inside. Adding to the functionality of this garage-ready upright freezer is how it sits on four, heavy-duty caster wheels. Reposition the freezer easily if you need to use the space for other storage needs or a special project.

On the inside, you’ll find heavy-gauge wire shelves and baskets, with adjustable positions to store and sort frozen goods. Door shelves and bins keep tiny goods within easy reach. All in all, there's 17.8 cubic feet of space of food storage. And while this model isn't compatible with an ice maker kit, it does keep your food chilled at the right temperature thanks to electronic controls.

If you don’t quite trust the natural, automatic defrosting cycles of a freezer, then consider this small Danby model that has manual defrost. It has a mechanical thermostat that can be set anywhere from -11 to 10 degrees Fahrenheit. When it comes time to manually defrost this piece, you'll want to pull everything out so you can scrape any thick ice chunks off the interior and cooling elements.

This is quite a tedious task, but luckily this particular model isn't too large. With an 5.9-cubic-foot capacity, it has just enough space to store anything extra that wouldn't fit in your main freezer, but won't overwhelm you on cleaning day. You can organize your frozen food using five shelves that quickly attract cold air. Once you close its reversible door, you can be happy with the fact that it runs quietly and remains reliable.

Although this model may not have every single bell and whistle, it certainly will get the job done and fill your needs. It's slightly more cost-effective because of the smaller capacity, but also because it runs on about half the energy of other upright freezer models, at 256 kWh compared to nearly 500 kWh per year.

An upright freezer doesn't have to be just a freezer. The Samsung RZ11M7074SA proves it, as it can be set as either a single freezer or refrigerator compartment. To get started with this convertible model, just hook it up after it's delivered to your home, and set the interior temperature between -8 and 44 degrees Fahrenheit. Ideally, you'd want to set the temperature around 0 degrees if you want to store frozen food inside, and 36 degrees if you want to store fresh items like produce, dinner leftovers, or drinks.

A power freeze option allows you to reach those prime, chilly temperatures as quickly as possible. This puts a little more power behind the fan, so the model can circulate the coldest air for up to 50 hours. Despite this high-functioning element of design, the appliance is still Energy Star-certified, and won't rack up your bills in the name of extra storage. Not to mention, this upright freezer has a reversible door, bulk storage baskets, a frost-free design that ensures you don't need to manually defrost it, and a power indicator. It may not be the most spacious option on the market, but is ultimately convenient, versatile, and reliable.

This upright freezer does a lot to make it easy for you to store and access food in whatever way is best for you. It offers almost 18 cubic feet of space to store your grocery store goods, and prioritizes accessibility with bright, LED lighting and five door bins. You can use these bins to store smaller items such as a pack of butter or pre-made smoothie, so that they don't get lost in the back.

In addition to those five door bins, this model also has one bulk storage basket and four shelves that'll help keep you organized and stress-free. If you typically worry about your items getting too frozen, you'll also love the interior electronic temperature controls in this model that let you tailor your experience, as well as its frost-free design. This takes away the need to manually defrost your freezer, which can be time-consuming and annoying.

Overall, this upright freezer doesn't shy away from style or functionality. With a stainless steel exterior, it'll fit in well with your other kitchen appliances or could even be placed beside its matching refrigerator.

What to Look for in an Upright Freezer

Capacity

The interior of an upright freezer is measured in cubic feet. It can range from as little as 3.0 cubic feet, to nearly 22 cubic feet. The larger the capacity of your model, the more you can store, so you'll need to consider how much you want to store before buying. The average upright freezer has around 16 cubic feet of space, and is divided up with four or five shelves, as well as a basket. To put this in perspective, that's enough space to store 560 pounds of meat.

Manual vs. automatic defrosting

Upright freezers either manually or automatically defrost. If a freezer manually defrosts, that means that ice and frost will build up in the interior over time. To maintain the model and ensure the cold air can flow evenly, you must unplug the model, remove everything from inside, and give the frost some time to melt away. You can speed up the process by chipping away at the frost build-up, before then draining the water, and plugging in your appliance. Automatic defrosting eliminates this routine, and allows the model to regulate itself. This type of freezer is also known as frost-free or self-defrosting, and can make your experience much easier, but will cost more to operate and purchase upfront.

Temperature range

The temperature range of an upright freezer will determine what you can store inside of it. In most models, this range goes from -10 to 10 degrees Fahrenheit, which is ideal for storing meats, fruit, or baked goods for long periods of time. Compact or budget models typically have a smaller range, and only allow for the internal temperature to be set between -4 and 7 degrees, while convertible models can be set as high as 44 degrees. To find the right fit for you, consider what you're storing, and know that the internal temperature range is separate from the exterior temperatures your upright freezer can withstand.

Standout Features

Garage-ready design

If an upright freezer is garage-ready, it can be used in an outdoor setting where temperatures can be very flexible. Despite a very hot or cold external environment, the unit will run reliably and effectively. A garage-ready model is most suitable for households who don't want to eliminate space inside their home for more frozen food storage, or want their appliance to have several installation options.

Quick freeze setting

When you turn on your upright freezer for the first time, or add new items to it after going to the store, a quick freeze setting will help the internal environment get cold fast. When activated, it'll override the temperature you set, and circulate the coldest air possible. It will continue for up to 50 hours—packing in the flavors of your meats, fruits, and vegetables. This is useful for households who want an entirely hands-free experience, or are interested in a convertible model.

Reversible door

An upright freezer with a reversible door can be opened by swinging the door to the left or right. This is a convenient feature if you plan on installing your freezer in a tight space or cluttered garage. You'll notice that this type of door features recessed handles and airtight seals. The seals can become worn over time, but be replaced if needed.

FAQs

How do I set the temperature on an upright freezer?

To set the temperature on an upright freezer, first locate the temperature controls. The controls could be a manual dial, which you turn to your desired setting, or an electronic panel, where you tap buttons until the readout shows the proper internal temperature. To properly store frozen food, you should set the internal temperature to 0 degrees Fahrenheit. Some upright freezers have a warm temperature or door alarm that'll notify you if the interior gets warmer than that.

How do you organize an upright freezer?

When organizing an upright freezer, or any freezer, you want to keep one rule in mind: first in, first out. In doing so, you won't forget about certain packaged meats, and inevitably throw them away after you find them months later. Another tip to follow includes putting your fruit, frozen meals, or vegetables in their own designated storage bins. In addition, plan to store bread and butter in the door bins, as it's a bit warmer. For more, check out our guide on how to organize a freezer.

What is better, a chest or an upright freezer?

In terms of space, an upright freezer is better than a chest freezer. It has a smaller footprint, leaving space for other items in your home. Upright freezers are also easier to organize— since shelving and door bins provide many thoughtful organization options. In contrast, chest freezers use less energy, and are less noisy. This is essential if you want to save money or are planning on installing the unit in your home. For more, check out our guide on chest versus upright freezers.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was written and updated by Marisa Casciano, who is the large appliance expert for The Spruce. Throughout her career, she's researched the ins and outs of air purifiers, dishwashers, cooktops, and more in the home and lifestyle space. As an avid cook, she knows the importance of finding a freezer that's both spacious and reliable.
item.dc:creator: Marisa Casciano

item.title: The 8 Best Bottom Freezer Refrigerators
item.description: A bottom freezer refrigerator can make it easy to see the food you're storing. We researched the top picks for every household and budget.
item.content:encoded:
When you come home from the store with bags of fresh produce, deli meat, and ice cream, the last thing you want to worry about is where to put it all. For most families, a bottom freezer refrigerator puts your most used items right at eye level, and provides plenty of room for your frozen goods, like veggies, frozen meals, and—of course—ice cream.

It's possible that you need a counter-depth model for when you're living in an RV, or need a bit more room than the average household, and we've got you covered on all accounts.

Here, the best bottom freezer refrigerators for every lifestyle, budget, and specific need.

For a well-designed and functional bottom freezer refrigerator, look no further than the Whirlpool WRB322DMBM. This appliance has it all, from a sleek and simple exterior that'll be easy to match in your kitchen, to a temperature control system that'll bring your groceries to their ideal temperature without wasting a boatload of energy. It will work to keep your produce fresher for longer as well, using its FreshFlow technology, which absorbs any excess gas that would make your food spoil. Ultimately, that technology will help you save money, too.

Given its price point, the WRB322DMBM also offers a generous amount of space for your groceries. Its total capacity is 22 cubic feet, with almost 16 cubic feet of that space in the refrigerator portion. The five shelves in the fridge allow you to keep your goods organized, and the freezer has sliding baskets for bulky items that'll allow you to access even the most tucked away bag of frozen chicken.

All in all, this bottom freezer refrigerator gets you the most bang for your buck, and has many notable features that'll help you overlook oversights, like the fact that it has no butter keeper.

For a bottom freezer fridge at a bottom dollar price, it’s hard to beat the value of the Amana ABB1921BRW. This appliance offers the conveniences of a bottom freezer configuration without a price tag that'll melt your bank account. Available in white or black finishes—or shiny stainless steel for a small upgrade charge—you can add this compact but efficient fridge to your kitchen with total ease.

While there aren’t a lot of fancy features on this model, it covers all the bases. In the easy-to-access fridge, you’ll find gallon-size door bins to fit milk or juice, and humidity-controlled produce bins. The control panel is front and center, making it easy to adjust settings, and maintain optimal fridge and freezer temperatures. In the freezer below, you’ll find wire shelving, a pull-out basket, and in-door shelving to keep everything neat and organized. You really can’t go wrong with the Amana if you need a budget bottom freezer refrigerator.

If your budget allows you to add a bottom freezer refrigerator to your space that's more expensive, then the KitchenAid KRFF507HBS is a sleek choice. It features a black stainless steel exterior, paired with slim, stainless steel handles. This combination, in addition to an external ice and water dispenser, will give any kitchen a gourmet look and feel.

When entertaining, you'll likely receive positive comments from guests, and enjoy the spacious interior that is perfect for storing many side dishes at once. With a 27-cubic-foot interior, this fridge definitely doesn't skimp out on space. The refrigerator uses around 19 cubic feet of this space, and includes five glass shelves, two produce crispers, and a pizza box slot for putting away leftovers easily and properly. The freezer, on the other hand, uses just under 8 cubic feet of space, and has both tiers and dividers that'll make organizing your long-lasting items a total breeze.

One issue you may run into with this fridge is that the ice maker may leak, or have ice build-up around it. The model may also run a bit noisy. Otherwise, this fridge will be a great, high-end addition to your home.

For a counter-depth bottom freezer refrigerator, the GE GLE12HSPSS is a great option. This slim refrigerator has an eye-catching, stainless steel finish and offers 11.9 cubic feet of total space. The counter-depth design means it will sit flush with your countertops, making your kitchen appear very high-end.

But, where this appliance is stylish, it's also quite functional. The refrigerator has a total of seven shelves for organizing your fresh food. A temperature-controlled drawer separates the fridge and freezer portions, and is the perfect spot to store easy-to-reach snacks or drinks. A bottle storage rack can even store your bottles of wine, eliminating the need for a separate wine cooler. Most notably, the freezer features a removable tray so you can maximize this section, and make sure your most-used items are right on top. With a lower-than-normal price tag, it's really a pick that's hard to beat, assuming you don't want a water and ice dispenser.

This LG Electronics model maximizes your refrigerator and freezer space, but doesn't make compromises in the process. It still comes with modern amenities such as easy-to-clean shelves, LED lighting, and an ice maker. The 8.3 cubic feet of frozen food storage may be the most notable part of this appliance though, as it'll hold any tubs of ice cream, wrapped-up meats, or frozen vegetables with ease. You can organize everything in the two provided baskets, and make use of a deli drawer and gallon door storage in the refrigerator portion as well.

The modern technology of this appliance ensures that no matter how much you pack it with grocery store goods, everything remains at its ideal temperature. The automatic defroster, for example, reduces the amount of frost build-up. Electronic temperature controls also give the appliance more control over the environment it creates.

Although the fingerprint-proof, stainless steel exterior may not stop a child from leaving their mark on this fridge, any prints will easy wipe off and this purchase will ultimately be a win.

Do you prefer a French door refrigerator? If so, the Whirlpool WRF535SWHZ is a great choice that’s big on size and style.

This French door refrigerator with a bottom freezer offers 25 cubic feet of space inside and a fingerprint-resistant, stainless steel finish outside. The sides of the fridge are a textured gray, which is typical for most stainless-steel fridges. Some well-loved features on this refrigerator include the interior water dispenser and in-freezer ice maker. Typically, a water dispenser can be a difficult feature to find on a bottom freezer fridge. However, the French door design of this Whirlpool model makes it possible.

Now, the 7.4 cubic feet of freezer space isn’t quite as large as some other bottom freezer fridges. But, any household will likely find it to be big enough. The drawer in the freezer is a solid bin instead of a wire basket, too, so small items won't slip through. If you have the space to install a piece with wide-swinging doors, a mid-priced and full-featured model from Whirlpool is certainly a quality choice.

When you are looking for the most versatility and convenience in a refrigerator, the Samsung RF23J9011SR is hard to beat. This refrigerator features a set of French doors on top and a freezer on the bottom. However, the freezer is split into two separate compartments. You can turn one into a refrigerated section if you need more storage for fresh foods. Then, if your frozen food stash starts to get bigger, you can simply set the compartment back to freezer mode.

Ultimately, the Samsung 4-Door Flex is the perfect refrigerator for a household that doesn't need a lot of bottom freezer space, or wants their experience to be both flexible and reliable. The only catch with this refrigerator is the circulation mode can be a little noisy. However, once you get used to it, the possibilities of this refrigerator prove to be super practical and worth the cost of the model.

Being able to open up your refrigerator and pour yourself a glass of water is a luxury this Haier appliance understands. It has an internal water dispenser, as well as an ice maker which comes already installed in the model. When having your piece delivered and set up, you will want to make sure a water connection kit is included. You should plan to either have someone hook it up for you or to hook it up yourself. Once you have it set up, you can expect ice to be made quickly and regularly.

The biggest selling point on this freezer, other than the dispenser, may be how spacious it is. With 27 cubic feet of space and five refrigerator shelves, you can easily keep your produce and fresh goods organized. Each shelf is adjustable, which makes it easy to customize your fridge's layout. In addition, the bins of this model are slightly blue-tinted and the interior has bright, LED lighting, so you'll feel as cool as a cucumber when locating a snack.

Now for the downsides: The freezer may not be as customizable or spacious as the fridge section. This appliance is also significantly wider and taller than others on the market, so you'll want to measure your space ahead of time.

Overall, it's a great pick, for those looking for a functional and luxurious fridge that's able to provide well-filtered water on demand.

What to Look for in a Bottom Freezer Refrigerator

Type

A bottom freezer refrigerator is often defined by its door design and depth. The right fit for your home depends on the layout of your kitchen, your budget, and your personal preferences. When it comes to door design, your model can have a single door, two French doors, or multiple compartments that can be used as freezer or fridge space. When it comes to depth, you can choose from a standard-depth or counter-depth model, which will sit flush with your counters. If you want to spend less, then consider a single door model. If your kitchen is tight, consider a counter-depth model, but know it'll likely cost a bit more.

Capacity

The capacity of a bottom freezer refrigerator refers to the amount of space in all of the compartments combined, and is measured in cubic feet. Capacity can range from 11.9 cubic feet in narrow models, to 27 cubic feet in larger ones. You'll want to consider not only the total capacity of a fridge, but how this number breaks down between the fridge and freezer compartments. An average-sized household can typically fit a week's worth of groceries in a model with around 15 cubic feet of fresh food storage, and 6 cubic feet of frozen food storage. Also, keep in mind: the amount of space a fridge has is affected by its depth. So, a large household should consider a standard-depth model over a counter-depth one to maximize their interior.

Ice and water dispenser

A dispenser is not a necessity, but it is a common feature in bottom freezer fridges with a French door or multiple door design. Typically, a dispenser is located on the door of a model, and dispenses ice and water at the push of a button. Some dispense both crushed and cubed ice. High-end fridges also have dispensers with auto-filling technology, which senses the size of your cup and fills it accordingly. Your budget and the size of your household will determine whether or not your model includes a dispenser, and how advanced that dispenser is. Bottom freezer fridges with a dispenser can cost more, and that dispenser can take up interior space. If you have a large household, consider how one will impact the capacity of your model.

Standout Features

Easy-open freezer handle

It can be difficult to open the freezer portion of a bottom freezer refrigerator, due to the weight of both the materials and your frozen food. Models with an easy-open freezer handle allow you to gently lift the handle, before easily sliding out the entire compartment. This is particularly handy for larger households who may be purchasing high-capacity models, which are naturally bulkier and more filled.

Factory-installed ice maker

Factory-installed ice makers are already built into a bottom freezer refrigerator, so you don’t need to purchase or connect a seperate kit. This reduces the likeliness of needing repairs, or dealing with leaks in your kitchen. A household with remote workers, athletes, or avid water drinkers will find this feature most helpful, especially when paired with a water dispenser or built-in pitcher.

Bottle and can storage

Special storage for wine bottles and beer, seltzer, or soda cans is a convenient feature in many new refrigerators on the market. It keeps you from having to adjust door bins to fit these taller items, or designate another spot in your refrigerator for drinks. In addition, this organizational feature eliminates the need for a separate wine or beer cooler, however isn’t suitable for wine connoisseurs who should separately chill their whites and reds.

FAQs

How long do bottom freezer refrigerators last?

On average, a bottom freezer refrigerator lasts at least 10 years. Its lifespan can be lengthened if you properly maintain the appliance, avoid troublesome features like an ice maker that isn't pre-installed, and address any needed repairs right away. Every six months, change the water filter, if your unit has a dispenser. In addition, be sure to clean the condenser coils, check the temperature your fridge is at, and make sure the appliance is level. For more, see our guide on how to maintain your refrigerator.

How do you adjust the temperature on a bottom freezer refrigerator?

To adjust the temperature of your bottom freezer refrigerator, you'll first need to figure out if your unit has electric or manual controls. If it has electric, you can adjust the temperature using a digital pad on the exterior or within the interior of the unit. If it has manual, you can gently turn a dial to your desired temperature. (If the dial uses numbered tick marks, 1 is considered the warmest.) To safely store food, set the refrigerator temperature at 35 degrees Fahrenheit, and freezer to 0 degrees Fahrenheit.

Do bottom freezer refrigerators have more problems?

In comparison to other styles, bottom freezer refrigerators don't have more problems or require more repairs. However, they can cost more upfront and to operate per year, in comparison to top freezer or side-by-side refrigerators. In addition, since the freezer is on the bottom of the appliance, it can be a real workout to lift the pull-out drawer or heavy items out of the compartment. Be prepared for these "flaws" when purchasing your new model.

What is better, a side-by-side refrigerator or a bottom freezer refrigerator?

When it comes to side-by-side and bottom freezer refrigerators, there isn't one style that's undeniably better. A side-by-side fridge is typically more narrow, so it's a better pick for small or tall kitchens, and doesn't require you to bend over to reach your frozen food. In contrast, a bottom freezer refrigerator is usually more energy efficient, and can easily accommodate bulkier items like chicken nugget boxes or a roasting chicken. To find the best one for you, figure out your priorities and see what style checks off the most boxes.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was written and updated by Marisa Casciano, who is the large appliance expert for The Spruce. Throughout her career, she's researched the ins and outs of air purifiers, dishwashers, cooktops, and more in the home and lifestyle space. She grew up with a French door refrigerator with a bottom freezer, and is a big advocate for keeping this part of her home clean and organized.

item.title: The 8 Best Wine Refrigerators of 2021
item.description: You can now store your favorite wines in their own temperature-controlled refrigerator. We researched the best wine refrigerators for any wine lover.
item.content:encoded:
The wine world is fraught with pointed, opposing opinions, but one thing everyone can agree on is the fact that wine should be stored and chilled well, or the entire sipping experience is at risk. Enter the wine refrigerator, a temperature-controlled oasis for your reds, whites, and rosés. 

This appliance can be your happy hour’s saving grace, but, given the sheer number of options on the market, it might be difficult to know which model is right for you and your needs. Rest assured, whether you want a home for your collection of 50-plus bottles or need to fit your beer and wine all in the same spot, there’s a cooler out there that’s perfect for you. 

Here, the best wine refrigerators for your lifestyle and collection.

Your wine collection can be treated to the very best, thanks to this model by Frigidaire. It's a free-standing unit that can hold up to 24 bottles of your favorite sips, and features a see-through door that makes it easy to show off your collection when entertaining. You can divide your wine between seven shelves, and set the temperature anywhere between 41 and 64 degrees Fahrenheit. The set temperature will then display on the exterior of the appliance, so you can rest assured that your wine is in good hands.

Ultimately, this wine fridge covers all the bases, and doesn't come with a hefty price tag either. For that reason, it's our go-to pick for a wide range of households and those looking for something sleek, straightforward, and silent.

Not too big, not too small, with an LED-lit interior and sturdy free-standing design, this is the cooler that Goldilocks would undoubtedly pick—it’s just right. This cooler from NutriChef allows for both wine storage and display, thanks to its combination of horizontal and standing racks, so it will be right at home whether you use it in your cellar or kitchen. 

This model’s adjustable temperature ranges from 41 to 64 degrees Fahrenheit and its air-tight, automatically locking door guarantees a consistent environment throughout the interior. The NutriChef’s unique blend of precision and ease of use, without any frills, makes it our pick for the wine enthusiast who wants streamlined storage.

It doesn't get more stylish and functional than this wine refrigerator by Cafe, a brand that's known for prioritizing both the former and the latter. This model not only can hold up to 46 bottles of wine, but is also outfitted with an LED light wall that gently illuminates each bottle you store. When it comes time to entertain or add new drinks to your collection, you can dim the light wall and adjust the internal temperature with an app on your smartphone.

Connoisseurs and new wine-lovers alike can also make use of dual temperature zones, which divide the interior into two, separately-controlled sections. This is ideal if you're storing reds and whites, since they require different environments for an optimal tasting experience. To top these features off, the fridge will notify you if the door has been left open, and you can customize the handle to match the other hardware in your home, too.

This fridge’s storage space is divided into two separate chambers with their own temperature controls and displays, which allow you to chill your whites while keeping your reds delicately cool. The temperature settings range from 45 to 65 degrees Fahrenheit and you can fit as many as six bottles in each compartment. Despite the extent to which you can customize the cooler’s environment, its LED display makes it simple and straightforward to set up and fit to your needs.

Plus, the Koolatron’s sleek, compact design is paired with its low-vibration system. This helps it blend into whatever space or room you choose to install it in.

If the capacity of your new wine refrigerator is a top priority for you, then look no further than this GE Profile wine cooler. It can hold 57 bottles on its sliding racks, which are finished with beechwood panels. You can easily pack in your favorite wines, and pull them out for your next happy hour, dinner party, or holiday celebration. A reversible door, in addition to these flexible racks, makes it easy to grab your drinks, but doesn't let unwanted air slip into the interior either.

Now, this model doesn't have multiple chilling zones, but is no stranger to amenities like a stainless steel finish, and flexible design. You can install the fridge as a built-in model or a free-standing one, depending on the layout of your kitchen.

A dual-zone wine fridge is perfect for the household who enjoys both reds and whites. These two types of wine should be stored at different temperatures, so that the flavors and notes aren't ruined. Of course, dual temperature zones do come with a heftier price tag, but this Samsung model makes the investment worth it. It can hold up to 51 bottles, and allows you to clearly set the internal temperature with a central control panel. The upper portion is specifically made for storing 16 bottles of white wine, while the lower portion is designed for 35 bottles of red wine.

In addition to ample storage space, this appliance has thoughtfully included sliding racks, a child lock, and a stainless steel finish. It only misses the mark when it comes to smart features, but that's easy to overlook.

With a stainless steel finish and blue internal lights, this fridge blends seamlessly and stylishly into a row of standard base cabinets. Its aesthetic form aside, its dual-temperature features allow you to store all of your wines in one place. Whites chill on the upper level while the reds sit in the separate lower level, and it’s up to you to fine-tune each compartment’s specific temperature within the respective ranges of 40 to 50 degrees Fahrenheit and 50 to 66 degrees Fahrenheit.

The NewAir’s space efficiency is worth noting, as well. Although it’s merely 15 inches wide, its sliding shelves can adjust to accommodate bottles of just about every shape and size, and all varieties can be stored properly, too. This cooler can also stand alone. Its locking doors have optimal insulation and UV protection, and its compressor prevents the model from shaking up the sediment in your wines. All in all, no matter where it's located, the fridge will maintain a stunningly consistent and secure environment.

From a storage space perspective, this Frigidaire Gallery model is just about the best value for your money as you’ll find on the market, holding a maximum of 52 bottles. (That number may vary depending on the size and type of bottles you opt to store.) Its six shelves are adjustable to make stocking easy, and can also fit a range of 12-ounce cans, instead of wine bottles. This allows you to make the very most of this fridge’s roominess.

Its spaciousness makes it all the more impressive that this cooler holds a steady temperature through its vast interior. Whether you want to keep your drinks at a cold 41 degrees or a cool 64 degrees Fahrenheit, it has your collection's back.

What to Look for in a Wine Refrigerator

Capacity

The capacity of wine refrigerator can be measured in cubic feet, but is often measured in the number of bottles it can hold. The most compact units on the market can hold as little as seven bottles, while the largest can hold nearly 57 bottles. For both wine connoisseurs and amateurs, a unit that can hold 24 bottles is usually enough, even when split into multiple zones. This capacity has a good balance of air flow and storage space, and doesn't give the appliance a bulky exterior which can be hard to place in your home. It leaves room for large-form bottles that aren't a standard shape and size.

Installation type

A wine refrigerator is either free-standing or built-in. The type of design you purchase will determine how the unit is installed in your home, and how it looks next to your other appliances and cabinets. If you want your fridge to have a streamlined look, then you'll want to opt for a built-in model that'll be snug with your cabinets and sit flush with them. If you're planning to put your wine cooler in a living room, dining room, or basement, then a free-standing model will give you the flexibility to do so, and will typically cost you less.

Single-zone vs. dual-zone

The interior of a wine fridge is called a "zone." The model you choose can either have one, continuous zone which is outfitted with shelves and set to a single temperature, or two zones. A dual-zone model divides the interior into two compartments, which can have unique temperature settings. This type of design is handy if you're hoping to store both reds and whites in your unit. White wine needs a chillier environment than red wine, so one compartment of a dual-zone model usually has a temperate range of 40 to 50 degrees Fahrenheit, while the other has a range of 50 to 66 degrees Fahrenheit.

Standout Features

Reversible door

A reversible door allows you to access your wine fridge by either opening the door to the left or right. It's usually designed with recessed handles and airtight seals along both edges. Although these seals can become worn or less effective over time, this feature is handy for households with limited space, as it makes the model more flexible to install.

Safety or child lock

A safety lock, which is sometimes called a child lock, gives you the option to secure your wine fridge on a daily basis or while entertaining. If your household includes children or frequently has guests, it prevents unwanted entry and can ease your nerves. Typically, the lock is paired with a physical key or key fob, which should be stored in an accessible spot inside your home.

Door alarm

In the event that you leave your wine fridge's door open, or the door doesn't seal tight, a door alarm is very handy. It alerts you, either with a loud noise or notification to your device, that the door needs to be closed. This prevents chilled air from escaping, and the internal environment from fluctuating in a way that could ruin your wine. While this feature is typically found in high-end wine fridges, it can be worth the extra money if you have a special collection and are picky about how it's stored.

FAQs

Is it worth buying a wine fridge?

Unlike a refrigerator or washing machine, a wine fridge isn't an absolute necessity for every home. It's often considered an amenity, and addition to an in-home bar, outfitted kitchen, or finished basement. You'll want to invest in this appliance if you're a frequent wine drinker, entertainer, or host, or want to save space in your regular refrigerator. A wine fridge will add to the flavor of your wine by keeping it in the appropriate environment, and free up space in your refrigerator's door bins.

Do wine fridges use a lot of electricity?

Compared to a full-sized refrigerator, a wine fridge typically uses much less electricity. While you'll still run the appliance constantly, the internal environment isn't as cool. It requires less energy to maintain the temperature you set. Depending on the size of your wine fridge, it'll use between 100 and 500 kWh per year, while full-sized fridges use more than 500 kWH.

Can you stack wine fridges?

A majority of wine fridges on the market are not stackable, and shouldn't be stacked on top of another appliance. They should be installed according to their manual's instructions, either under a counter or in a freestanding spot in your home. If you want to maximize your storage without giving up any floor space, look for a single model that can hold up to 52 bottles or is very narrow.

Do you put red wine in the fridge?

Red wine can be stored in a wine fridge, but it is not recommended that you store it in a regular fridge. This is because a regular refrigerator usually has a much colder environment that can ruin a red wine's flavors after one or two days. Store red wine in a wine fridge that's set at 55 degrees Fahrenheit. Store it on its side, and in a place that's still. For more, check out our guide on how to store wine.

Why Trust The Spruce?

This article was written and updated by Marisa Casciano, who is the large appliance expert for The Spruce. Throughout her career, she's researched the ins and outs of air purifiers, dishwashers, cooktops, and more in the home and lifestyle space. She studied art and culture when studying abroad in Florence, Italy, and is a wine lover who understands the importance of properly storing reds, whites, and rosés.
